Author: thelink6899
Content:
I remember from a video you guys mentioned that the integrator of the future would promote best-in-class instead of being vendor specific.

What would you define as best-in-class for SCADA?

We’ve been using ignition and it is pretty great.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Best in class SCADA is not a single product but a range of products.  Ignition is in the group and leads the pack in our opinion.  FactoryStudio is an up and comer.  WinCC-OA is in there too.  Start thinking of the SCADA layer as a series of SCADA nodes surrounding a hub and you'll understand better what I mean.

Author: thelink6899
Content:
Thanks for the quick response. 

So, essentially a range of products selected based on a specific requirement?

I’ll check out FactoryStudio a bit later.  I am relatively new to SCADA, so have dived into ignition it is what we work with.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Here is what I look for in a SCADA  product -- open architecture, simple licensing, free training, cross platform.  I prefer SCADA solutions that are developed by companies that only do SCADA.  They must support MQTT and other IIoT protocols.

Author: jvan_van
Content: We recently did a light comparison between VT and Ignition for our new platform. VT is probably better as a traditional Scada system, and quicker to get running. But Ignition won out for its open architecture, flexibility, and ease of integration with anything you can imagine.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: VTScada is very much traditional SCADA.  Ignition is a platform for solving problems that is marketed as SCADA.  It is quite difficult to compare the two.  For I4.0 and IIoT and enterprise apps, its Ignition all the way in that comparison.

Author: evanwill.
Content: @Walker Reynolds rates Ignition as best in class. @DerekStickel is clearly not drinking the kool-aid. Why such strong polar opposites? #scada

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds rates Ignition as best in class. @DerekStickel is clearly not drinking the kool-aid. Why such strong polar opposites? #scada
@EvanWill Great question -- I suspect that we are measuring the platforms with different sticks.  What matters to @DerekStickel and what matters to me are likely quite different -- primarily because we work in different parts of the stack.  I suspect that we both agree that the solution needs to fit the problem and that there are many problems that he and I would agree on the solution.  It is important to note that Ignition is not really SCADA, rather, it is a platform for solving problems that is marketed as SCADA.  If you look at most of the solutions developed by our team with Ignition, you would be surprised to find that very few of them fall in the SCADA layer.  Ignition fits in every layer of the stack, as does FactoryStudio -- and they really are alone in that respect.  If you are just trying to solve a SCADA problem and nothing else, then I expect you could make a very compelling argument to go another direction.

I have learned so much from both guys, @Walker Reynolds has certainly cemented the unified namespace concept for me and @DerekStickel is a programmer with hands on practical experience that shines through in his posts. I am also fascinated that @DerekStickel is developing MachineView in his 'free' time and if you follow Derek you know that there is not much free time to speak of.

Author: Deleted User
Content: @MikeCurnow.com - Hi Mike, the cold hard truth of the matter is that most data stored in relational databases cannot be loaded to Machine Learning, it needs to be transformed - you need to augment the data and aggregate it across different time periods. The transformation process typically takes a number of weeks or possibly even months to get it to where it can be loaded to ML and build a useful model. We have automated this process (for the most part it was deemed to be non-automatable) - so we can have the data ready for loading to ML within a couple of hours of processing. We then do other stuff including AutoML and output of SQL code too, but that aspect is our main USP

Author: takko_the_boss
Content: As someone who co-owns an algorithmic ForEx trading platform, I know the plights of enacting machine learning for almost anything. I can definitely see this being the case. Whether dealing with structured or unstructured data, the data all needs to resolve to a normalized format you can feed to your models. Automating that would take considerable effort, however if you have proper data normalization schema and modules to enact such, then I can see you being able to automate.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @MikeCurnow.com - Hi Mike, the cold hard truth of the matter is that most data stored in relational databases cannot be loaded to Machine Learning, it needs to be transformed - you need to augment the data and aggregate it across different time periods. The transformation process typically takes a number of weeks or possibly even months to get it to where it can be loaded to ML and build a useful model. We have automated this process (for the most part it was deemed to be non-automatable) - so we can have the data ready for loading to ML within a couple of hours of processing. We then do other stuff including AutoML and output of SQL code too, but that aspect is our main USP
@Deleted User automating the normalization of this data is not really that difficult, honestly, but it has been a challenge for the industry -- the UNS is part and parcel of this normalization.  Data Scientists have been approaching the problem all wrong from the beginning (in industry, that is) and that is why nearly every ML initiative runs out of money or political capital before value is attained.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Data does have to be transformed -- or normalized -- namely to get the time series data from many rising and falling edges into a single series... but this is achievable without manual intervention through automation and architecture.

Author: takko_the_boss
Content: Using UNS to level playing field as data output is concerned would **considerably** streamline the process  💯 %

Author: Deleted User
Content: @MikeCurnow.com - Hi All and Mike, Happy to discuss this across the group if of interest to others, or take it off-line if it isn't ( my email if required niall.walsh@xpanse.ai ) - I agree that it is a challenge for the industry and has been for some time - and yes projects of this type are often constrained because of the current approaches and limited budgets. Our technology is best aligned with structured data, we work with the raw source data (in IoT this is often easier to get access to for a cloud solution provider than in FinTech, Telecoms or other). We take multiple data sources and automatically combine these with some historical Target event data, then we automatically generate many thousands of features/variables, all within a couple of hours. There is an in-built selection process which results in a managable table of features/variables/aggregates which we then load to an integrated AutoML component - you can get from raw source data to a deployable model within potentially a day (though more likely you will iterate a few times and refine aspects as you go).

Author: rkwadd
Content: There are dozens of standardization efforts trying to address this specifically to provide more structured industrial data to the data scientists that the Fortune 50 manufacturers all hired while it was the cool thing to do (possibly starting with Marco Annuziata’s 2013 TED Talk “Welcome to the Age of the Industrial Internet”). I’m oversimplifying here but basically the idea is that unsupervised learning is a waste of resources if we can all agree that “rotational velocity” is defined the same or similarly whether it’s a conveyor belt, a machine tool spindle, or an industrial mixer. The standards are normalizing niche vocabulary (PackML, AutomationML, MTConnect, bacNET), and then higher level frameworks are harmonizing across sectors (ISA95) or normalizing data management and communication protocols (OPC UA, DDS, MQTT sort of)

Author: rkwadd
Content: I should get an online cert in Data Science, say I have a decade of industry experience, and then land a $200k/yr job manually scrubbing excel spreadsheets for variations of {ALARM} and {_alarm} until the MBAs who hired me get wise and replace me with an intern.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: OPC-UA has a role in the architecture -- primarily on the edge but also between applications (nodes).  We still build discrete connections between nodes (application to application or application to hardware) where appropriate, but they are functionally specific.  The IIoT infrastructure is architected on an IIoT protocol, leveraging a unified namespace.

Author: emileackbarali
Content: Lately I have been diving down in the depths of OPC-UA, and it's powerful features, of which the data modelling and platform independent aspects are at the top of the list. It may be due in part to my own lack of exposure to the "right" plant installations, but I am seeing very very few real-world practical examples of these key aspects being leveraged to make a real difference. It's platform independent, but not a heck of a lot of platforms are implementing it. It provides for rich data models, but I am seeing it used mostly like classic OPC with discrete unstructured data points. MQTT is in a different space but what I am experiencing with it is almost a "network effect", that is .... the more it's being used ... the more it's being used, and then the more valuable it becomes. It has been implemented on quite a few (non-Windows) platforms. But I am not seeing this with OPC-UA. Again, it may be my lack of exposure. Would like to hear thoughts on this.

I've moved away from the platform for a few reasons -- most of which have to do with the fact there are better options by companies who are more attentive and agile, that cost a lot less, with a much shorter learning curve. Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Question of the day: What is your preferred SCADA platform (one word answer)?  What is the real world difference, in your eyes, between SCADA and HMI?
@Walker Reynolds I really have 2 -- Ignition from Inductive Automation and FactoryStudio from Tatsoft.  The real world difference between SCADA and HMI -- SCADA is plant or area layer visualization and HMI is on the machine.  HMI used to be the actual visualization and SCADA was just the control and data acquisition component -- but that is no more.

Author: gman_iotangle
Content: Can anybody help me understand the concept of MSSQL licenses core vs CAL licensed. If we use the MSSQL database with Ignition and let’s say I have 50 clients open. Will I need 50 cal licenses?

Author: gman_iotangle
Content: Or is there some sort of formula to look at connections etc?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: My favorite SCADA is Ignition, but the one I can really do things with my eyes closed is Elipse E3. For me the practical difference between SCADA and HMI is their importance on the floor, their level. We usually call HMI nowadays what is embedded on the machine whereas SCADA is usually monitoring a bigger context. But even for SCADA we talk about High Performance HMI, so that is why I say this is the practical concept.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Can anybody help me understand the concept of MSSQL licenses core vs CAL licensed. If we use the MSSQL database with Ignition and let’s say I have 50 clients open. Will I need 50 cal licenses?
@gman_IoTangle One license -- the gateway is the only technical client connection to SQL

Author: .dhess
Content: @Walker Reynolds EAM = Enterprise Asset Management (yes?). In my case it would be isolated to fabrication floor production equipment, gas cabinets and panels, 5S area designators, support tools such as Helium Leak Checkers, and Metrology tooling. I've got no control over it. The maintenance department is migrating to Xcite (bought out by Applied Materials) here in the near future. The 900 page API supports MES, and equipment maintenance histories, PM tracking, and all the common CMMS bells and whistles. By Technology stack I think you are referring to how the various kibbles and bits of equipment tie-in into Production Automation controls? yes? SECS /GEM? I'm still coming up to speed with your vocabulary. Thanks for the advice none-the-less. It's appreciated.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Yes SECS/GEM is technology — specific to semi-conductor... there are software solutions built for semi conductor like Conrad Kascik... they leverage technology like SECS/GEM but they are not technology... they are software solutions.  Build a technology stack and then pick software solutions that fit the stack.  Do not pick the software solution and get stuck with the technology they choose to use.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds EAM = Enterprise Asset Management (yes?). In my case it would be isolated to fabrication floor production equipment, gas cabinets and panels, 5S area designators, support tools such as Helium Leak Checkers, and Metrology tooling. I've got no control over it. The maintenance department is migrating to Xcite (bought out by Applied Materials) here in the near future. The 900 page API supports MES, and equipment maintenance histories, PM tracking, and all the common CMMS bells and whistles. By Technology stack I think you are referring to how the various kibbles and bits of equipment tie-in into Production Automation controls? yes? SECS /GEM? I'm still coming up to speed with your vocabulary. Thanks for the advice none-the-less. It's appreciated.
@EgoNoBueno Keep in mind there is a difference between and EAM and CMMS. Fiix software has a quick blog on the difference, but fundamentally a CMMS is for keeping track of work orders, repair history, spare parts, etc. An EAM focuses on the end-to-end life of an asset. Like many technologies, the line is blurring. Where I see a real need is for capturing reliability data (vibration, infrared, ultrasound, oil analysis, etc) in a UNS. From there is could be used for condition-based maintenance which would automatically generate WOs. There are a lot of wireless sensors that now provide online monitoring which are rather inexpensive. There are many differences in technology and what they provide. I would adopt a reliability centered maintenance strategy to determine where to add these. It should be technically feasible and economically viable.

Author: .dhess

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
> @DavidSchultz  Infrared...for circuit breaker panels? What's the emphasis? For vibration whats your favorite sensor?
@EgoNoBueno Infrared is commonly used for electrical enclosures, but other process equipment can benefit from its use. There are a number of temperature monitors that can track enclosure temperatures. I suggest these along with PM routes. Just be sure the capture the data in real time. There is a lot more available in the vibration space,  which makes it difficult to pick my favorite. As they say, it depends on what you are trying to do.

Author: .dhess
Content: Typically we walk around with a Flir 50 to scan for heat anomalies on individual breakers. I also use it to isolate hot spots on PCBs when troubleshooting.  Anything over 150F gives me indegestion.

Author: .dhess
Content: Tip O' the day. All you guys with PLCs should change out your CMOS back up batteries every 3 to 5 years. Add it to your PM. PM task "Change the PLC battery on the first quarter of odd years", or something similar. This will save you from a lot of goofy equipment  faults.

Author: mdowdell
Content:
I have two questions with respect to Factory Studio....

1.  What functionality does Ignition have that Factory Studio does not?
2. What functionality does Factory Studio have that Factory Studio does not?

Thanks in advance!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 1. Features Ignition has that FactoryStudio does not — Ignition can be an MQTT broker, FS connects to external brokers.  Ignition has a script console where you can test your scripts, FS does not.  Ignition has EAM for distributed gateways, FS connects servers together but EAM isn’t a feature.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 2. Features that FactoryStudio has that Ignition does not — FactoryStudio supports .net, c# and python scripting.  Ignition supports python only.  FactoryStudio treats all elements of projects as objects, browseable with intellisense, Ignition doesn’t do that.  FactoryStudio supports projects from multiple versions of the platform running alongside one another, Ignition requires that projects be upgraded to the gateway version of the platform OR taking one version offline prior to bringing the other version online.  But... for the most part... the platforms are very similar.

Author: mtcderek
Content: Security is based on the weakest link. This is an incredibly subjective question based on an incredible number of possible details. The router to the factory could be outdated and vulnerable, an admin's computer with access to the system could be vulnerable, social engineering is always a possibility, physical breaches are possible if someone literally steals the server. That question is really just asking for a summary of cyber security risks in general.

Author: Deleted User
Content: I mean like what all are the features in iot 4.0 that after its  incorporation we can be sure of more security

Author: mtcderek
Content: industry 4.0 is massive. You're going to need to step back and focus on specific pieces of it and secure them. Overall, your perimeter/WAN security is priority 1, but then you have several pieces within that can have a multitude of vulnerabilities. it's not just one piece of software that encompasses everything.

Author: r.pop
Content: Words from the IoT Cyber Security Alliance I think sum it up pretty well: There is no single solution that will secure the IoT at every level and every touch point. The only sustainable approach involves a multi layer, end-to-end framework that takes into account all connected devices, along with the applications they run and the networks they use to transmit information.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Does anyone know of an open source database or any other type of software, that allows you to replicate the evaluation of realtime expressions, such as a SCADA or a PLC can do? Example: tagC = tagB + tagA. So if any of the dependencies change, the value is revaluated, or even better if I can do this by time, for example, getting the tagC value at any specific time. Postgres 12 has calculated fields, but you need to use other columns on the same table so it is not something that you can easily do at scale as you would do in Pi or Ignition. I wonder if there is even something not focused on automation, such as a Redis or Postgres extension that allows to do that.

Author: mtcderek
Content: would views work? not sure the full requirements of this.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Not really, but thanks @dere@MTC-Derek . Basically, the case is to receive events by exception. So I want the flexibility to evaluate expressions, as simple as an and logic. Let's say I want to create an and logic having two digital tags as inputs. As they come by exception, when I do c = a and b, what I mean is that c = last known value for a AND last known value for b. They did not arrive at the same time. I've done this with database using simple operations like one operator and two inputs as formula, entering ids as inputs. I wanted something more sofisticated like expressions in a SCADA. SCADA is statefull so the inputs are tags on the server RAM. Going to the database, I'm not really handling a table of current values for each tag but a table with key, value and timestamp. Expressions are not as simple as they require a compiler to provide tag browsing and intellisense. I also wanted it to be stateless backed by a database, so this "real time expressions provider" could run on 1 or N instances at the same time, getting the current values from a 3rd server, a DB server that can be a single instance or a cluster. In short, things that are simple to do in a plc or SCADA can be done with views on a database, but that is not scalable as it takes much longer to write each specific view than writing an expression on a PLC. I'm just venting actually but my thought is if something can be done with a database that handles only real time or last known value as the plc database and SCADA tags database are, there should be a pattern to replicate this behavior on a SQL table. Have you seen something that mimic this behavior, whether for OT or not?

Author: mtcderek
Content: i know node-red, for instance, can hold state for values, aggregate asynchronously, etc. Of course, that's just javascript running in the background. it seems like many streaming analytics platforms should be able to do something like that. it's been a long day, so i may have misread your requirements.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: InfluxDB has an opensource plugin that does expressions...

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Thanks @MTC-Derek ! Streaming analytics seem to be more the case. I'm taking a look on CDAP. For some projects it might be too much but I'll dive a little more into it.

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> InfluxDB has an opensource plugin that does expressions...
@Walker Reynolds thank you! I have always used other timeseries options like Timescale but I guess it is a time for me to take a closer look to InfluxDB.

Author: ricardoolsen
Content: @Mario Ishikawa, MongoDB has the change streams feature that can be tied to a Node.js (other languages are also supported) app to process incoming data asyncronously. This works like a database trigger but in a process external to the database server. I am building a SCADA system using this feature, I can assure you it works very well. Great for real-time processing, not so good for time series data.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Thanks @RicardoOlsen, that looks great and it seems to be comparable to PostgreSQL Listen/Notify. I never used it though but I wonder if you happen to have compared them. Still, that would need something like a different script for every formula, is that really the case? BTW, I took a look on your scada repo. That's a great job. Congrats! And I saw you are using Timescale on it. Nice choice.

Author: ricardoolsen
Content: This PostgreSQL mechanism I didn't know about, very useful, thanks @Mario Ishikawa. You can store formulas as Javascript code in the database and then do eval() in the change stream app, so only one process can handle all formulas. I think the same approach can be used with PostgreSQL trigger/notify/listen, it would be interesting to compare the perfomance. Mongo can scale horizontally, this can make a difference for very big systems.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Very interesting to know about the possibility of eval(). Thanks @RicardoOlsen!

Author: mtcderek
Content: i used postgres listen/notify a good bit with nodered. it was great for quick scaffolding.

Author: mdowdell
Content:
@js On-prem versus cloud is somewhat of a difficult topic to address quickly in this medium, but I will try. I hope that I don´t ramble. too much.

My primary role is sales and I spend a lot of time with OT. OT is very interested in getting their data out of machines into an application where they can create information. In many cases (not all) IT have been the CAVEmen - against everything. IT will not provide infrastructure nor engage with OT to find a mutually agreeable solution or their solution is so limited in scope and accessibility that nobody uses it; dooming the initiative to failure. In cases such as this, we offer a cellular connection to the cloud where we have Ignition or some other app running. The purpose of this end run is to provide OT with a positive experience that then forces IT to come back to the table. Of course this architecture is limited in scope and data transmission, but you can do some interesting things - OEE calcs, asset monitoring, alarming, alarm notification, etc.; all at a rudimentary level.

Author: mdowdell
Content:
@js While most of our solutions start in the cloud, they routinely end up in On-Prem or a hybrid (On-prem and cloud) which is the most powerful and has the attributes required for a robust, comprehensive I4.0 solution. Knowing that your solution must be deployable in the cloud and on-prem take time some time in the beginning to do your research. For example, if you want to work with a great cloud solution provider and you spend a lot of time ($$$$) developing a slick application, what will you do when the customer says "that application is great and solves our pain points!. I now need it running in our site!" What are you going to do? How much more $$$$ will you need to charge the customer? How will your customer feel about the charges for additional work? Also, know that, sooner or later you will need IT infrastructure (switches, routers, etc.) . The amount of data that will be moving around can get quite large. Especially in an environment that has edge functionality and analytics, On-Prem SCADA coordinated with local HMI, and cloud services. All of these components/topographical areas will be needed sooner or later.

After working in a multinational, CPG company for many years one thing I learned and profess is that the Operations - operators, maintenance techs, and all other front line people that work directly with the machines are our CUSTOMERS and know more information pertinent to our work than anyone else. Just remember, even the plant manager works for them. We must always keep this in mind while "listening to the voice of the customer."  You must seek out the operators. It is a long chain of interdependent  service providers that enable operators to do their job. It seems to me that in many organizations certain departments, or job titles, have forgotten this fact - with IT being one of them. Just remember, if you want a project to fail - piss off the operators.

Author: mdowdell
Content:
@js With all that being said, if IT can be pulled in from the beginning THEN DO IT. Life will be much easier and your project have access to additional, invaluable resources. More excited partners, more $$$$ for projects. Also, more smart people thinking of ways to make these projects successful. Sorry for rambling, but I think that I answered your question.

One last point that I want to mention with respect to IT. Manufacturing organizations tend be "top-down" driven. This means that the IT guys in the plant take orders and follow procedures by someone in "corporate." Many times, the plant´s IT guys want to help, but they just do not know how or feel restricted. This issue can make I4.0 projects difficult in plants located far away from corporate. In these cases, I work with the local IT guys and provide them with all the information they need to present the case from the "inside" and during this process, I create an "champion" with whom I share a common vision.

Author: walker.reynolds
bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
@mdowdell, I really appreciate the thoughtful response.  Cloud vs On-Prem can, even still today, be a contentious subject.  Some of its practical (e.g., latency) and some of it is impractical (e.g., intimidated "cave men").  I'm fortunate enough to be an environment that is infrastructure-agnostic.  It helps when your org has relied on SaaS ERP/MES for nearly 15 years.

The simple answer to the question of infrastructure is, of course, "it depends...".  I was curious about diving into the technical specifics.  I was curious about the different scenarios and seeing how each of us approach them differently.  We are fortunately to be living in a time where technology does not necessarily narrow our options as it has in the past.

Sometimes these decisions are governed by investment cycles and where already available infrastructure resides.  I wanted to go beyond this and think about optimal design.

I have attached a mock-up of two very different approaches.  Perhaps this might be useful to "riff" off of.

I'm curious if any of you have a go-to solution that you continually come back to in your projects.

Author: sasanka9171
walker.reynolds
Content: @sasanka a couple of things — you have a huge amount of data because you are storing values that do not change.  Switching to report by exception changes that and reduces data.  Second, the UNS isn’t all realtime and historical data in one place — it is the structure of your data in a namespace, it is the last value of the data stored, it is a list of all clients that are subscribing to specific parts of the data and it is the events of the data — as a value changes or a state changes, the UNS fires that event and notifies the client.  It is the client’s job to do with that data and event what it will (like storing it in a data lake).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is why OPC-UA is not the future of IIoT — because if we use OPC-UA then our events and value changes are no longer lightweight, they are very verbose and will not scale as we deploy across the enterprise.

Author: abram7918
Content: @sasanka I'm looking into a hybrid solution. Bulk data on prem, selected data necessary for corporate purposes in cloud. A solution which allows you to run queries on real time data and on historical data or both seems the most versatile solution. Someone else commented that many apps they built in the cloud frequently ended up on prem. This needs to be factored into where your data is.

Author: zackscriven
Content: How could we integrate Discord into an enterprises #scada Infrastructure? Would that not be sick? Having alerts and messages in discord.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'll be honest, I'm not a gamer and am very new to Discord.  I have not looked into using Discord in the enterprise.  From an end-user perspective, it's impressive.  Slack, MS Teams, and Webex Teams are the usual suspects in the corporate world.  These have robust tools for managing compliance and large/complex user base.  They are also used with other things.  As bad as it sounds, they're more likely to be IT-sanctioned.  Regardless of the tool, the idea is plugging in collaboration tools into the digital factory is brilliant.

We currently use workflows/integrations in Slack for the more "human" events in the factory that the automation space can't necessarily model well (not well currently, at least).  We have a Slack channel for each cell.  These have a set of workflows to request assistance.  They also receive notifications from MES and QMS (e.g., dimension out-of-spec, deviation).  They've worked well for triaging with offsite support.  It's also an easier way to communicate in a noisy environment (especially with smart watches).  There is a ton of potential for integration with SCADA.

I found some interesting links...

Inquiry about Alarms for WhatsApp
https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/module-for-senting-alarm-pipeline-messages-to-whatsapp/25323

Ignition's Slack Alarm Notification SDK 
https://github.com/inductiveautomation/ignition-sdk-examples/tree/master/slack-alarm-notification

MQTT Client project for Slack.  If alarms & events are published to a UNS/broker, they could presumably be subscribed to by a messaging app.
https://github.com/jpmens/mqttwarn#slack

ServiceNow, an IT service management platform, is a tool I've wondered about.  It's exceptional at managing complex IT environments.  The automation is slick.  Increasingly, it's become a swiss army knife for enterprise workflows.  It's starting to spill over in other areas (e.g., HR, finance, field service, customer service).  I wonder about it's potential use cases in a digital factory.

Author: sasanka9171
Content:
@Walker Reynolds we have been using Wonderware InTouch/Archestra for the SCADA. Most of my target Manufacturing plants work in isolation. And certain plants are integrated. Given the pretty high Market share that InTouch/Archestra have in the SCADA-HMI Segment, should I stick to InTouch/Archestra? 
If I put in other way what would be the compelling reasons to consider solutions other than WOnderware InTouch/Archestra for SCADA & HMI ?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Aveva to Ignition conversions make up about 2/3 of all SCADA migrations in the market today.  The answer to your question is complicated because it is should be based on the strategic problems you are trying to solve.  Aveva, like Siemens, is starting to move in the right direction.  That is, they have created a new vertical line of products that do support or will support many of the technologies that are report by exception, edge driven and open architecture.  That being said, very rarely do we recommend that a client stick with their current WW architecture -- its not that we never make that recommendation, but we rarely do.  To give you a comprehensive answer, I'd have to look at the overall digital maturity of the organization, the human capital, the strategic vision -- identify risks to success and design an architecture.  The 10k answer is, it is not likely that Aveva solutions are the right solutions for your organization.

Author: sasanka9171
Content:
@Walker Reynolds thanks for sharing the insights and information. I am being asked typical questions like, I don't see that many Ignition Developers as many I find the InTouch Designers/Developers. Also the variance in 
 the size of the companies is also being looked into. This question is being asked given the recent acquisition of OSI PI by Aveva.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I wouldn't look at size, I would look at the growth curves -- Aveva is going in the wrong direction (their market share is going down), IA is the fastest growing automation company in the world -- 9 straight years.  When I started working with Ignition, they had less than 2% of NA market share, last year, they hit 38% on greenfield and touched 30% on brownfield.  They make up 2/3 of all migrations.  Who is asking these questions?  Aveva acquired OSISoft for the same reason Rockwell partnered with PTC -- they needed to hide their declining market share from their investors.  Whoever is raising these objections -- they need to look at growth curves and revenue per employee, its not even a close comparison.

Author: waveguide3e8
Content:
@zackscriven @js Hi, I'm new here and I'm looking to learn so sorry in advance if my idea is a little out there. You both have mentioned Discord, Slack, Teams, etc. One podcast I listen to called the Ask Noah Show has introduced me to **matrix** which is a decentralized/federated but also potentially self-hosted messaging service.
https://matrix.org/
I haven't tested it myself but generally speaking it's designed with the thought that you might want to have something that is closed off or air-gapped from the world but still have the full functionality of a collaborative messaging platform. They have plenty of documentation on how to develop and integrate with it.

It makes me wonder... what if instead of email notifications or having to check HMIs, what if you instead could join your SCADA Matrix, maybe use VPN on your mobile device to connect remotely in safely - and then you get notifications? There could be channels for Alarms. New data. Metrics and KPIs.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Are people embedding external libraries in their Ignition and Factory Studio projects to interface with external apps?  Does this work well?

My colleagues and I have taking a liking to MVTec's HALCON platform for machine vision.  HALCON is a vision library with its own IDE and run time.  It can be embedded in or interfaced from an application using a variety of languages (e.g., C, C++, .NET, Python).  Most implement HALCON projects with custom .NET apps as the interface.  In terms of efficiently interfacing with automation, I've begin to wonder about leveraging an open SCADA platform like Ignition or Factory Studio.

Author: tgchip_1235
Content: What are the reasons that you prefer HALCON over the Matrox or Cognex vision libraries?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Much of it is application-driven.  3D capabilities for metrology and surfaces.  Functionality to combine/overlay point clouds from multiple sensors and CAD models.  Wide support for image acquisition.  Well-supported by certain laser sensor producers.  Run time licenses are economical.

The downside is that there is a pretty steep learning curve.  Other solutions (e.g., Cognex VisionPro) are far easier to get started with.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Have you embedded or integrated any of your vision applications into SCADA or IIoT platforms?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I read that and I wonder what exactly it means. Will it then become a AWS integrator? Will IA SIs become also AWS SIs?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It means they have a supported reference architecture for on-prem Infrastructure-as-a-Service.  It's probably more of a formal way of saying "Yes, this can be done. It works. We'll have your back."  When an end user calls IA, AWS, or an SI; there is less likely to be finger pointing.  

Deploying third-party apps (i.e., not your own), especially industrial or engineering apps, on IaaS can sometimes be difficult.  The companies that create and use these apps can be conservative and myopic.  They don't know cloud infrastructure or really care to ever learn.  Many have never even tried or experimented.  Additionally, engineering and services can use "unsupported config" as an excuse for everything.

Author: marioishikawa

Author: michael.brown
Content: This might be more of a "cloud" conversation - but its fairly straight forward. Azure Virtual Networks are already private, they allow outbound internet by default. You can modify this using their Azure Network Firewall, Security groups, OS firewalls, or lastly 3rd party network appliances (think next gen firewall / paloalto etc..). If I were doing it and the requirement is PRIVATE. I would create a virtual network, setup a Point to Site VPN and add the vpn client to my edge node. Then install the ignition infrastructure on VMs as normal using security groups to allow connectivity to the Database of choice (i'd use a manged DB) then I'd probably also use a network firewall and kill all outbound internet traffic so only VPN traffic was allowed.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: So, Inductive as a certified for AWS Outposts, what exactly that mean? That their software can be used on AWS Outposts or that IA can install these servers like a AWS partner?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Happy to see you are pretty happy with it 🙂

Author: michael.brown
Content:
TL;DR - IA is a technology partner, so their software has been installed and tested on outpost. They are not consulting partner and will not install or support them. the rest below : 

"AWS Outpost Ready" partners come in 2 flavors. 
1. Technology Product
2. Consulting Service

Inductive Automation is a Technology partner - meaning their software has been tested against a baseline:
(SEE HERE: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLhr1KZpdzukf2K67aldy_A1pAC-SkpPWz)
Also, the product has been physically installed and tested on a production or LAB Outpost and the baselines are passed on the Outpost as well. 

Both Ignition and OSI Pi have this certification in the industrial space - 57 other software platforms are certified and growing.

The Outpost is fully managed and supported by AWS. So that means our teams or possibly a Consulting Service partner will show up and install it. The new versions are 1U or 2U in size - they are self-install and require no on-site visits.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Vision is for CI/CD long-term -- technicians, electricians, maintenance personnel can easily create visuals for innovations they are working on.  The biggest value driver of Digital Transformation isn't getting data in the hands of data scientists (its valuable, but not the biggest) or IoT developers.  The biggest driver is unlocking potential on the plant floor by enabling edge employees to innovate.  You need a mechanism to get them the data, allow them to turn it into information and present it for consumption -- vision is perfect for the last step for the edge employee.

Author: mparris
Content:
I've never used vision, only perspective.

Is what you are saying about vision being good for the plant floor because getting a display going is simpler? (Perspective is architected around JSON and CSS and not intuitive to most?)

I saw in the 8.1 release they now have perspective templates, so maybe it will get easier over time?

In either case, giving people on the plant floor sandbox Ignition Edge Panel devices to do what they wish would be interesting. The best use-cases get to be operationalized at the Enterprise level :smiley:

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Developing in Perspective is much more labor intensive and far more technical than vision by a factor of 100

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: At its base level, vision is drag and drop -- including bindings.  You don't have to worry about views, css, etc at all... vision is really good for quick, easy, low/no code dev for non technical people.  We do all of our initial UI dev in vision and then build in perspective once we want to scale up and deploy to production.

Author: andyott33
Content: I agree with that statement now that I have gone through the practical. It definitely required quite a bit of research and collaboration to develop the perspective portion of the practical. Specifically, I found vision tables much easier to configure and edit compared to the perspective tables.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hadn’t thought of it that way, excellent points! Unlocking innovation is one of the key arguments I use for why we need to get this train going!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Another way of thinking about it is this: Vision is your live wire-framing and innovation tool... the innovation is driven from the edge and once vetted by the IIoT team and the business, can be developed in Perspective for wide adoption and scaling.  You can create and test value very quickly in vision... which lowers the barrier for 'trying' new ideas.

Author: chrisgele
Content: We converted a large water utility back in 2017 from IFix to Ignition primarily due to cost and functionality.  This was before we knew much about Industry 4.0, but it turns out it was the first step in the right direction.  Our client did know that showing trend data and report data could work so fast.  We also helped them migrate their old historical data into Ignition.

Author: jasperlouage
Content: That is great. What are the functionality Ignition has that IFix does not?

Author: jasperlouage
Content: I'm not quite sure how to interpret 'not open' sometimes. You probably can read and write data to IFix, no? What is meant with a platform being not open?

Author: chrisgele
Content: @Jasperlg IFix may have changed since our implementation in 2017, but at that time we could not choose which database we wanted to use. 1) IFix required the IFix Historian product.  Retrieving data for purposes other than SCADA would require additional software and engineering time to make this functionality work (we wanted to move operational data to a CMMS system for preventive maintenance tasks).  If we could have used any SQL database, everything we needed to do would only require writing some SQL queries.  2)This utility is constantly growing and the need to expand the system would require additional costs in licensing (additional tags, additional historical tags, additional clients, etc.).  3) Redundancy, Ignition only requires a few settings to implement redundancy.  If I remember correctly, IFix tag databases had to be moved or copied to redundant servers. (This may have changed since then)  4)Data types and structures Ignition offered more options in this area at that time. 5) Support, GE/IFix support was a multi tiered offering that required a phone call to the distribution channel, then if necessary the distributor would contact GE/IFix.  With Igniton I speak directly to them.  Support in our area was not very good with GE/iFix, and Igniton was and still is very supportive.  There are probably some others, but these were the most important ones.   Hope this helps.

Author: matthijsprent
Content: RSLinx looks like a Rockwell product. I have not read much positive things about Rockwell.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm not familiar with Citect.  Without knowing more details, it's difficult to provide advice.  Could you be more descriptive about RSLinx not reading tags?  Is the issue with communication between RSLinx and the PLC or RSLinx and the software?  Are all these applications residing on the same Windows server?  Or, multiple ones?  There might be a DCOM configuration issue.  Review the installation steps in the product manual.

RSLinx is useful to connect Rockwell software to Rockwell hardware.  RSLinx has embedded OPC server functionality, but it's hardly worth using.  I would recommend using one of leading third-party products (e.g., Kepware, Matrikon).  They have better diagnostics and better define data types.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Also, are you able to choose block and individual reading? I'm not familiar also with the stack, but if you read by block and there is one single tag wrong, you don't get the block at all. If you can change by single tag reading for the test maybe you can catch the problem.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I had a brief encounter with Citect. That installation had native Allen Bradley drivers for Allen Bradley. I didnt think you needed RSlinx for this?

But if the system is not supported anymore, you can build a system next to it and compare it. When the newer is appoved, you can get rid of the old one.

Content: GG @Jon Forbord, you just advanced to level 8!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
A lot of great discussions around OPC-UA here.  The issues with OPC-UA are:

1. It isn't edge driven without adopting part 14 pub/sub (which recommends MQTT for the transport layer)
2. It isn't truly report by exception in most cases
3. It isn't lightweight -- it is a very verbose standard
4. The standard tries to be everything to everyone -- as such, the standard is 75% optional so we see far too much deviation between vendors who adopt it 
5. It was developed at a time when serial networks were king, Purdue security was the standard and server/client, poll/response was the architecture

I see a lot of potential with Part 14 pub/sub, assuming the OPC Foundation can fix the underlying issues with the standard itself (point 2,3,4) AND someone can develop a super lightweight implementation to run on even the most under-provisioned hardware (see all entry level PLCs and HMIs).  

Considering MQTT Sparkplug B is out there competing against OPC-UA, I just don't see a reason to put OPC in the middle of the architecture.  OPC-UA is great on the edge to integrate legacy infrastructure into an IIoT ecosystem (built on MQTT SPb) but it is still lacking to become the future of I 4.0.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Regarding 4. - I'm having to make my OPC UA to MQTT gateway differently from all the different PLCs I'm interfacing with. With one I can grab tags by groups, with another I have to grab single tags. I'm thinking this is because the adoption is different in each PLC, but I'm just assuming here.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
It's verbose because OPC UA uses XML and SOAP over http or is the standard overall verbose or is it both?

Can it be an option for the OPC foundation to prefer the JSON format instead of XML and thus clean up on the message level?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: That would help -- but the limitations go deeper than that.  The standard itself is verbose (massive and bloated), and some of the technical decisions made prior to adoption make implementations of the standard also verbose and bloated.  This is primarily because of the mechanisms used to browse the namespace and the mechanics of subscribing to and reporting on changes to opcItems.  OPC Foundation is going to need to fix this using part 14 of the standard -- by stripping out the bloat and verbosity for pub/sub implementations because it is far too late for OPC-UA proper in poll/response implementations.  The OPC-UA models aren't the problem so much as the standard wrapped around those models and the technical overhead required simply to serve, browse and access them.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is a problem with many embedded OPC Servers or IoT protocol interfaces.  They're a bolted-on communication module that functions as if it were a third-party product.  They can't always "shoehorn" native memory structures into rigid tag-oriented namespaces.  IMO, this can be attributed to technical limitations and a lack of imagination.

I believe it comes from an old-school HMI mindset:  create a logic subroutine for the visualization, expose the tags to the communication interface, and build the context in the HMI program.  Everything is hardcoded and modified on as-needed basis.  Nothing is architected in a way that would dynamically publish or consume data.  From a product management perspective, some believe that publishing a raw tag one-by-one without context is viable.

The other culprit, I suspect, could be performance constraints of the hardware.  Some embedded interfaces are from third-party commercial SDKs that were added after the fact and/or not necessarily optimized for the platform.  It allows them to go-to-market with support for a standard with minimal investment.  The unfortunate result of this might yield tag count limitations, inconsistent handling of datatypes, or awkward management interfaces.

Have you considered leveraging the Bosch Rexroth PLC's native protocol?  Can it expose symbolic addressing over something like CODESYS or SERCOS III?  It's not unheard of for third-party OPC Servers to have have superior support to native ones.  It might also be worthwhile looking into if there is a native SDK available.  Those IndraMotion units are basically PCs and have pretty elaborate front ends.  I wouldn't be surprised if they had a .NET library or Windows driver available.

Another option is to do nothing and consume as-is.  Some machines and controls were architected as silos.  It can be cost-prohibitive making certain assets natively "edge-driven".  Instead, one must create their own edge elsewhere and perform transformations there.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: There’s a Bosch rexroth SDK, but not supported for this NC controller as far as I understood. I haven’t checked the native protocol. I do have the possibility to export the xml of the symbol configuration, I was thinking I could find a way to leverage that.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I’d be surprised if it was hardware constraints, as this is a ridiculous piece of hardware, up to 256 axes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Most OPC-UA servers and clients are the "UA TCP" implementation.  This is a binary encoding.  The web service implementation supports XML (or even binary) encoding over SOAP.  This version is exotic and has been basically deprecated.  Because it requires each node to parse XML and support HTTP, it's less performant than its TCP binary counterpart.

Very few products, especially devices, have implemented the web service spec.  I believe the thinking was that this spec was apt for exchanging data among higher level systems.  When the UA spec was wrote ~15 years ago, SOAP was the premier technology for integration in enterprise IT.  Microsoft conceived the technology and it was pushed in reference architectures.  This, theoretically, provided UA with interoperability among software applications.  Although, this never really took off.

OPC-UA, regardless of encoding or transport, is verbose because of the standard.  It has a very "rich" object model that is seldom utilized.  It's one of most complicated ways to exchange what is, in practice, little more than name and value pairs.

To use an analogy, suppose one ordered ten books from Amazon.  Normally, Amazon would fulfill the order with packaging to protect the contents and optimize cost.  But, this time, Amazon packaged the books inside of a library.  They shipped a whole library.  And it's not just any library.  It's a national or top research university library.  It has immaculate facilities, unlimited book shelves, archival capabilities, the best technology, the best faculty, all organized, etc.  It has everything one would need to learn or research anything.  But, it only contains the ten books that were ordered.  With a "glass half empty" mindset, one might say this is overkill.  With a "glass half full" mindset, one might be pleasantly surprised by the library and all it can enable.  But, eventually, one becomes disappointed it can only be used as a book shelf.  This is what it feels like to use OPC-UA.

Author: mparris
Content:
To continue the analogy, it's like buying a digital book. It's fast, secure, and can be read by lots of devices like smartphones, kindle, etc.  Also, the best feature of all is that the digital book promises to transfer knowledge straight to your mind just by opening it! 

But after getting it, you discover that the best feature isn't used because the book didn't include that; you missed it in the fine print.  Unfortunately, you still have to read it word by word.

Author: kennethds.
Content:
Hi all, 
I’ve been reading discord back and forth and I truly love the idea of a single source of truth. 
The question that remains stuck in my head is when to use which communication protocol. 

For example;
MQTT, OPC UA, S7 connection. 

PLC -SCADA com. for process control. the PLC is capable to publish to the MQTT broker, has  an onboard OPC UA server and obviously can use S7 com.

Which one would be preferred and more importantly why?
Is it wise to use MQTT for process control?

Content: Pinned a message.

Author: kennethds.
Content:
@zackscriven 
Thanks for your input 👍
I agree, we shouldn’t send process control over the cloud with whatever protocol. 
Let’s assume we use ignition as local SCADA and also give it a role as local broker, or as a local OPC UA server. What’s the difference? We still send process control from the ignition SCADA to the PLC. Why would one choose OPC over MQTT in this case? 
Isn’t the sparkplug spec intended to be used in “real time” applications?

If this statement is correct then MQTT can be used for process control, with the right type of PLC there is no more need for point to point connections. 
Or did I misunderstood something along the way?

Author: zackscriven
Content: I would lean towards MQTT. If it's for like a control room?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You didnt miss the point... yes... SPb can be used for Process Control and it is, regularly.  @zackscriven is pointing out that Process Control should happen as close to the edge as possible.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I was under the impression OPC UA was used for control due to its verbosity. But MQTT SpB for transfer of data. This is based on a comment that SpB could be used for control, but it's not a good idea. Same reason I wouldn't want to use wireless instruments. Can you please clarify?

Author: mparris
Content:
At one end of the spectrum, Engineered controls to offset safety risks are not appropriate for SpB, that's where protocols like Safety over Ethernet/IP or EtherCAT come in. 

At the other end of the direction, handling user inputs from an HMI is definitely within scope of SpB.

Then there's the mushy middle where it depends...

Motion control may be another application not appropriate for SpB, depending on the scan rate needed or, again, the results of a safety risk assessment and Machine FMEA.

Author: mparris
Content: I've also been struggling with the phrase "on the edge," and have lately been thinking in terms of inside the IIoT Ecosystem or outside the IIoT Ecosystem. SpB is great for driving the IIoT Ecosystem. There are lots of protocols great outside the ecosystem, and the requirements determine which is best to use.

Author: mparris
Content: Seems the list of protocols for outside IIoT Ecosystem is decreasing, thankfully. I would start with OPC-UA, SpB, EtherCAT, IO Link, and, for nostalgia, our good friend Modbus

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: They aren’t mutually exclusive... but more based on the solution fitting the problem.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Very good explanation, Matt.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I tend to use OPC at the control layer as often times Kepware is already installed. What is the decision criteria? I have people ask about native Ignition drivers to PLCs, but am a fan of fit-form-function. Hence Kepware.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Would you say EtherCAT is the best in class within the fieldbus-space? Looking at the metrics for Profinet, SERCOS and a few others, EtherCAT at least has the best metrics.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: https://www.manufacturingtomorrow.com/article/2016/05/5-real-time-ethernet-based-fieldbuses-compared/8044

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: My opinion is that EtherCAT was the right solution at the wrong time — it got lost in the shuffle because EthernetIP emerged and took over due to ease of implementation and super low overhead needed for scanning.  However, on the merits EtherCAT is a top performer and is ideal for super high speed telemetry at the field layer.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: In just about every use case, this is the way to go — OPC is generally already there and supported, its robust, you’re on the LAN (so being lightweight isn’t important yet).  I stay away from Ignition drivers in all cases except for PoC or quick testing.  IA are not experts in developing drivers (and they don’t generally license someone else’s drivers like Tatsoft does).  Kepware is the gold standard in native driver to OPC-UA conversion and that is the direction we go for integration of legacy systems AND process control for those systems.  However, as we move up the stack (or up the network layers) we increase the likelihood SPb will take over.  In greenfield solutions, we are native SPb or DNP3 all the way up the stack in nearly all cases — but that is still a fraction of implementations.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @MParris has outlined a couple of other solid criteria above

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Thank you. That was my impression. But I hear conflicting answers, and realizing they are based on context, want to get a better grasp on decision criteria. It's guidance. Not gospel.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Exactly, if it were gospel, the client wouldn’t need an architect to help them with the decisions.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In most cases, it doesn't really matter.  Most applications can achieve probabilistic determinism with even the least performant standard.  There are, of course, niche applications that will require specific solutions.  What fieldbus one deploys is more of a function of hardware platform they deploy.  One does not get the freedom of mixing and matching.  Unfortunately, many of these companies govern these standards as somewhat of a walled garden for their own ecosystem.

EtherCAT = Beckhoff
SECROS-III = Bosch-Rexroth
EtherNet/IP = Rockwell
PROFINET = Siemens
Powerlink = B&R

EtherCAT is really cool technology.  But, as mentioned earlier, it's late to the game.  And a lot of applications don't necessarily benefit from it.  It's like hot rodding a minivan or heavy duty truck.  It either can't make use of the additional power or it doesn't help it fulfill its purpose any better.  It's a classic "weird flex, but okay" scenario.

EtherNet/IP is unique in that it leverages the standard Ethernet stack unmodified.  There are pros and cons to this.  The greatest pro is that it doesn't require an ASIC.  Whatever the IT or consumer tech world use, so can EtherNet/IP.  This makes it easy to implement and adopt.  This is why some vendors (e.g., Schneider, Omron) have preferential support for EtherNet/IP along with other protocols.  Combined with other technologies (e.g., PTP, TSN, 1000BASE, 10GBASE, TLS, DTLS), EtherNet/IP can handle a lot of complex applications.  It's not the fastest or most elegant technology, but it's the most poised for adoption and growth.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Has anyone integrated an electronic signature device? For an automated loadout / ticketing station??  It working with an Ignition application and we have a community member who was tasked to integrate a digital signature system. Any ideas?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yes, but with MES and ERP type applications.  It's very common for shipping & receiving documentation (e.g., bill of lading, commercial invoice, customs).  When it comes time to implement a shipping operation at a site, Topaz signature device is one of the first things deployed.  It quickly eliminates unnecessary scanning and administrative overhead.  Beyond that, the occasional quality application comes up (e.g., certificates).  Unfortunately, I have not encountered this for SCADA.

As for your question regarding Ignition, I wonder if you could leverage that reporting module?  Is there some sort of method exposed in the scripting to consume an image and "stamp" it in a form?  A lot of signature capture devices can be exposed as a TWAIN device.  Unfortunately, I was not able any sort of TWAIN interface for Ignition.  You're probably stuck leveraging an SDK for a signature device or image capture.  Topaz has all sorts of options.

Recommended SDKs:
-Dynamsoft Web TWAIN (HTML5 interface for image capture / scanning)
-Topaz SigPlusExtLite (browser extension interface for topaz)
-Topaz SigPlus Pro Java  (java interface for topaz)

Another option is to look into DocuSign.  They have tons of integrations and strong APIs.  It's also great if you need a closed-loop with legal or formally control the documents being signed.  You could have your loadout station workflow fire off a DocuSign envelope and then wait for the signature to be executed.

UPDATE
Whoa.  Just stumbled upon this.  You're in luck.  There is now signature capture functionality directly within the Perspective module.  You could avoid the signature capture device all together and, instead, leverage a touchscreen or tablet.
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC80/Perspective+-+Signature+Pad

Author: IIoT#4707
Content:
These are the Minimum Technical Requirements for your IIoT Ecosystem:

1. Edge-Driven
2. Report by Exception
3. Lightweight
4. Open Architecture.

Author: zackscriven
Content:
OPC-UA (ask anyone in this group and they'll tell you) it falls short on almost every category...

1. It's server driven... Not edge driven.

2. It polls all data regardless of what's been changed.

3. It's verbose and heavyweight.

4. It's not entirely open. Not nearly as open as MQTT with a Sparkplug B Formatted payload.

With my amateur eye, Thingsboard just looks like a platform to enable visualization, and I can't see how docker containers can be managed using this platform, so if you have any insights, that would be much appreciated.

Author: faithware101
Content:
Thingsboard as an Open Source IOT backend that has also paid version, offers more than you need for a typical complex IOT application. 
You can manage your devices and their attributes, the mqtt broker will forward your Data to the rule engine that triggers your custom actions and of course data storage. Also thingsboard offers a Dashboard editing tool that let's you easily make quick visualisation of data. Thingsboard REST API gives you the ability to access your data and to integrate other tools. I think most organisations can design industry 4.0 solutions based on thingsboard as the main device manager, data archiver/retriever and custom actions executor.  
On the paid version there is a hole bunch of feature that are really amazing. If you have any questions am here to exchange with you guys!

Author: faithware101
Content: @MParris also thingsboard has microservice architecture that let's you be able to deploy it using docker, kubernetes Or swarm. This will make sure that your mqtt broker is always on and the rule engine is working at all times which is very important.

Author: benveenema
Content:
It's a good question. If we leave the UNS "open" for writes in addition to reads, could we get into an issue where someone unknowingly creates an unsafe condition or makes a button to turn off someone else's machine when they're not looking? For these reasons, we might want to make the UNS read-only for some user groups. However, that isn't enabling innovation at the plant floor as much as allowing writes would. Perhaps we can make PLC/Edge tags read only for some user groups but allow them to push new tags in if they choose?

As far as structure, since the UNS is edge driven, it would be difficult for an unknowing person to "mess it up" but they could pollute it by pushing data to namespaces where it doesn't belong. Anyone who's used a shared network drive knows how messy it can get. I think this is best solved with education vs lock-down. Maybe after an employee has gone through their initial training and become familiar with interacting with the UNS through their dashboards, they attend an in-house workshop on how we build simple dashboards and organize data. After that, they get access to creating their own dashboards?

Just my thoughts. I'm curious how people further along their 4.0 journey are handling this.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
Haven't got around to it yet, but the plan is to let operators play with the Perspective Dashboard-component (did see a demo of this, but cannot find it atm.. - https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC80/Perspective+-+Dashboard ) to be able to put together dashboards with metrics that they wish to see side by side that does not do that by design. That way we can learn new ways and needs to improve the SCADA-system further. Implementation of the outcome of this and other views / functions will be done by trained personnel.

Settings, dependencies and such that is going to be published to the UNS will there fore only be available as set up by design, and I can not see that the operators can do much harm. *The System-designers however, will have infinite ways to f_ck it up.* 😆

Author: benveenema
Content:
Once the environment is configured, Ignition Designer - Vision Module is pretty drag and drop friendly. There are deeper connections, like indirect bindings and scripting that might be outside of some operators abilities, but leaving these exposed will identify the intrinsically motivated people with the ambition to go further.

I understand that some operators, especially older operators don't have enough computer skills to access Ignition Designer. I'm not picking on them, it's just a reality of having not grown up with computer/technology but the younger generations, millenials and gen z (or whatever we're calling them now) will likely find the basics intuitive.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is called Homogenous and Heterogenous development.  Homogenous is the stuff your integrator does, its common across client access points.  Heterogenous is the custom stuff, generally deployed by the user or a specialist in the organization, and it contains the custom or unique features needed for a process, a person or a function.  We develop the UNS and the UI to incorporate both together, even on the same screens.

Content: Do I need a UNS if my SCADA and MES (AVEVA) are connected or can connect to other systems?

Content: Pinned a message.

Author: abel03833
Content:
My opinion is that many of the legacy SCADA\Historian systems were not designed to be a UNS. They will have some connectivity capabilities, but it might involve doing a lot of point-to-point connections. So, I think you still need a platform that serves as UNS, and treat existing SCADA, MES, Historians, etc as nodes that reads & feeds the UNS. The UNS will have the additional connectivity capabilities to integrate data from new devices like edge gateways. 

Interested in hearing other points of view

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Yes you need a UNS even if your SCADA\Historian\pickyourpoison can connect to everything, because there is no application (and nor should there be), that can do everything. If you rely on pulling all data into ONE system, you'll have to do everything in this application. One of the benefits of a UNS is that the state of every application in the business is available to any application that wants to make use of this data to create new data or information. This will enable innovation on a level that can't be achieved by relying on ONE application to do everything. Back in the 3.0 days, developing the functionality that involved more than one system, would require such an effort, that it was limited to high value targets. With a UNS, the effort required to develop this type of functionality will require a lot less effort, and therefore have a increasing likelyhood of being cost effective, and thus implemented. With everything in a SCADA, the functions you could develop would be limited by what tools are available in the SCADA system. This is better than no unified data, but still doesn't offer the flexibility on solutions that a UNS offers.  My 2p.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
@Randy Lesovsky asked:  *Hey guys! I was wondering if the ignition driver for Allen Bradley serial does in fact work with all Allen Bradley serial PLCs?Specifically a SLC 504 serial.*

Ignition's AB drivers are Ethernet-based.  In the SLC series, only the 5/05 processor has a native Ethernet support.  The 5/04 does not.  There are three options:

1)  Add a hardware Ethernet gateway to the SLC 5/04 (e.g., NET-ENI, ENTB, RTA 1761-NET-ENI Replacement).  This will convert the processor's native serial protocol (DH-485, DH+) to Ethernet.

2)  Replace the SLC 5/04 processor with a 5/05 processor.  This will provide native Ethernet connectivity

3)  If you have an existing infrastructure that communicates with one of the legacy AB serial protocols (e.g., DH-485, DH+, DF), you could leverage a software gateway.  If it's feeding into an RSLinx or ControlLogix somewhere, you could tap into these by deploying an OPC server such as Kepware.

In an ideal world, I would advocate for an overhaul replacing the SLC with a CompactLogix 5380 or the popular options in this community (e.g., PLCNext, Groov EPIC, S7-1200/1500).  Those SLCs are end-of-life, parts becoming more expensive, and it will become a greater technical limitation in digital transformation down the road.  This is the most costly option.  

Next best option, in my opinion, would be to replace the processor with a 5/05.  This requires a simple program transfer and re-config.  This will provide native ethernet connectivity to the memory table.  It bypasses any serial protocols and eliminates the need to deploy a gateway in the field.

If you insist on keeping the 5/04, add an Ethernet interface.  I believe Rockwell has discontinued these.  Real Time Automation offers a great replacement.

Lastly, whether you opt for the 5/05 natively or a 5/04 with a gateway, I would recommend using the Kepware's AB Ethernet driver instead of Ignition's.  Kepware can expose the data to Ignition via OPC-UA or MQTT.

Author: markritchie8899
Content: Ignition Topic Management Question. I have ignition up and communicating with 4 PLCs. Using MQTT Engine to populate tags which will populate when the PLC is connected to the network. My topic structure is  DCNET/AVTEM-R1-B1-G1/NDATA/EDD2132882-35855/. When I disconnect and move the PLC to a new subnet  DCNET/AVTEM-R1-B1-G2/NDATA/EDD2132882-35855/ the tags populate and stream as expected under the new topic ("G2") but the old tags remain in the previous topic("G1"). I see the topic shift(G2 appears and G1 disappears) in MQTT explorer. Would appreciate how this housekeeping is managed in ignition.

Author: scamananak
Content:
Yes, experienced that, it happened to me exactly the same way. Ignition guys told me it's a bug with ignition 8.1.7 and it is fixed as of 8.1.8. Is that your version?

I found it wasn't related to how you create the tags. It's just a bug with UDT's in general. Since the update,  I haven't had any vanishing UDT tags fortunately

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @George Newbold, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: scamananak
Content:
If you publish to AVTEM-...-G2 instead of G1, 
this should create completely new tags in ignition and the old G1 tags should remain. That is expected behavior. If you have Sparkplug_B set up, the NDEATH and DDEATH messages should signal to ignition that those tags are offline, then you could make a script using the tag quality param to delete it using: system.tag.removeTag("Tag1"). I suppose you dislike your tag browser being filled with dead tags?

In MQTT explorer, you should see a new topic and payloads, the old topic and payloads will be cached in mqtt explorer and still appear but no longer on the broker. I don't know of any mechanism for the topic to 'shift', afaik the old topic remains and the new topic will be created separately.

With a node client I can subscribe to NDATA and NDEATH which can be monitored for a changing message for a given bodied. Would be interested in how you go about this for a SCADA where everything is subscribed (DCNET/#) and I don’t know what the future nodeids will be in the future.

Author: mparris
Content:
I asked this question on the inductive forum
https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/mqtt-engine-auto-prune-removed-metrics/

Author: mparris
Content:
It is a slight difference from your question, but similar concepts.

My question is regarding a node that stays in the same group and node, but publishes a new birth certificate that has a metric removed (because it was decided to stop publishing that metric for some reason). In this case in my opinion, a birth certificate confirming a metric missing should be sufficient justification to have MQTT Engine prune this automatically.

Author: mparris
Content:
Your question is a bit different. Ignition doesn't know that G2 is actual the previous G1 that just changed its groupID and nodeID. For all it knows, G1 was powered off and at any time it can come back on.

I've found when this is actually the case, that having the stale tags in ignition is useful to show that the equipment was connected and now it isn't, and I can see the timestamp of the last transmitted data for troubleshooting.

Author: mparris
Content:
I've thought about how to prune tags, and have considered creating a perspective screen that allows a user to delete nodes and all tags underneath it to clean it up when needed.

I'm be curious to know of any algorithms to automate this, knowing the difference between zombie nodes and nodes that are valid but temporarily offline

Author: jon.forbord
Content: If it’s just a change of nodeID, perhaps you could make use of the client ID of the mqtt connection? Other than that this has the smell of a two generals type of problem, meaning there’s no solution, just workarounds that work most of the time.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Jon Forbord, you just advanced to level 12!

Author: mparris
Content:
Ooo... Using the client ID is a cool idea. 🙂

I guess iff the client ID is the same as the node id, and so works also change when moving the node, it wouldn't help.

I love the suggestion, though!!

Author: uddersnz
Content:
Hi folks, bit of a newbie question here about a SCADA / MES logging pilot. Not doing the whole plant yet, just a (large for us) pilot system of around 30 robots and 100 conveyors.

I need scada connected to the PLCs for troubleshooting / status display, and would like to add in detailed realtime downtime reporting. Hoping to set up a UNS and run MQTT messaging. Looking at Ignition at this stage, and have the obvious noob question of Vision or Perspective? Being able to embed Perspective sessions in our existing tablet interface for our mobile robots would be nice, so kinda leaning that way. Any strong opinions on this?

Also dashboards / reports is where I want to push for my I4.0 aspirations, and I have seen some sexy looking tatsoft dashboards in the background in some of Walker's videos. Ignition is our corporate standard in the U.S. but I have some discretion here in NZ. Should I push on with Ignition, or pause and check out Tatsoft's offerings. Will they get me what I need in terms of scada as well as reporting / dashboards?

Any advice gratefully received!

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Duncan Thomson, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: If you go with Ignition, the decision to develop with Vision or Perspective boils down to two things:  1. Do you need native mobile?  If yes, then Perspective. 2. If you don’t need native mobile, do you have web development experience?  If yes, then Perspective.  The advantage of Vision is ease of development, lots of support available in the community, short learning curve.  The advantage of Perspective is native mobile and fully reactive screens.  The downside is you really should web development skills or expect a longer learning curve.  RE: Tatsoft or Ignition, basically anything you can do in Ignition can be done in FactoryStudio.  The advantage of FS over Ignition is speed and price.  FS uses .NET, C# and Python for scripting, Ignition use Java and Python.  You cant go wrong either way… we are using FS more and more lately.

Author: uddersnz
Content:
Thanks Walker. I'm a PLC guy who started my career with some scada, now moved into robotics as well. As such Vision is probably better for me short term. But looking further ahead, my software guys are more web based with .NET and C#. 
So at this point, probably Perspective, but FS still holds some interest, so I will check out their demos. Cost will be a benefit here too, although I can potentially squeeze a little more for Ignition as it is an approved standard for our corporate owner.
Thanks for the feedback, very useful!

Author: mparris
Content: If looking for a temporary proof-of-concept HMI that doesn't require mobile, then vision should be okay. If developing something for the long haul, go with perspective. Eventually, Vision will be phased out.

Author: uddersnz

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: How does everyone determine the scope of their projects within Ignition (or similar)?  How much content are you putting into one project?  Is it an entire plant?  Or are you standing up separate projects for area, line, cell, etc?  Do you prefer one or few "large" projects or many "small" projects?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: As they say, it depends. For a small plant, the SCADA system will control the plant. There may be a few stand alone systems for utilities like compressors, chillers, RO water, etc. These are connected to the plant system. For large plants, there will be a system for each area, but there will still be a plant system. The advantage to Area systems is that they can still operate while other areas are offline. But there is a greater cost.
