Author: pvmagacho
Content:
When selecting a SCADA system, and looking into performance aspect, what normally is used? I give a few examples.
1- minimum Tag update time in the server
2- minimum Tag update time in the screen
3- maximum screen transition time
4- minimum failover server transition time
5- etc
I don't see any SCADA system providing this type of information. Also, demo applications are small sized and not useful for such benchmarking.
Is this the wrong way of looking into performance. 
Specially, because a SCADA with bad performance can lead to unsafe situations.

It will publish to the broker but ignition will ignore it. Is anyone aware of a list of which characters used in topic tags will cause problems in Ignition.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
*Specially, because a SCADA with bad performance can lead to unsafe situations.*

The way I interpreted this statement implied that SCADA systems, depending on their performance, can be either safe or unsafe.  If I misinterpreted this, please let me know.

SCADA, as the name implies, is a supervisory control function.  It's not intended for controlling anything related to safety.  It's like an HMI, but for a larger scope (e.g., Area, Plant, Enterprise).  Theoretically, one could place an E-Stop button on an HMI screen, but they don't because HMIs are not a safety-rated device.  The performance of a SCADA should have not bearing on its safe operation because it's not intended as such.  The role of critical control and safety are for PLCs and DCSs.

If anyone else would like to chime in on this, please do so.  I'm not as well-versed in the process industries and DCS.  I predominantly focus on discrete manufacturing.  The way I think about this is that a PLC controls a process whereas a SCADA supervises the control of a process.

Author: uddersnz
Content: Yes, what js  said above. Safety wise, it should be a non-issue. SCADA has two more levels below it: the PLC and the safety controller. Typically the safety controller won't allow the PLC to endanger humans, and the PLC won't allow the SCADA to endanger the equipment.

Author: pvmagacho
Content: I mean that a slow SCADA can lead the operators to errors and not allow them to fix any problem with the plant and cause a unwanted stop of the process

Author: lvta0909
Content:
Well, afaik that's not always true on o&g offshore units.
The operator can bypass/override control and also interlock functions, for maintenance or as a procedural requirements. Obviously following directives, requiring permissions and such.
There is a safety PLC/controller, and it does (or should have) have special procedures/requisites for the operator to comply when interfering with the safety features, but nevertheless more times than not those situations occurs.
On such situations an unresponsive scada system can lead to proccess stops or in worst cases scenarios to accidents if the operator fails to understand the proccess situation.

Author: lvta0909
Content:
I second what Paulo said.
I've seen scada systems (recently deployed) taking more than 15 seconds to transition screens. Performance limitations that requires the load to be distributed against several servers.
Those things annoys me specially when I compare it with solutions with 10+ years running till today, which are of similar complexity and didn't face these problems (granted those were openvms/vxl and not windows based systems).

Author: mparris
Content:
I ran into this when we were trying to use a slash in the sparkplug groupID.

From here:
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC81/Tags#Tags-TagNaming


When you choose a new name for your Tags and folders, there are some rules that must be followed. The first character of the Tag name must be one of the following:

Any alphanumeric
Any valid unicode letter
An underscore
The second character, and every character after that can then be one of the following:

Any alphanumeric
Any valid unicode letter
An underscore
A space
Any of the following special characters:

'	-	:	(	)
All other special characters can not be used in a Tag name.

Author: iiot_advisor1814
Content: I agree David totally about the independent systems for monitoring each "area" - but an overall 3rd party remotely connected (cellular) health monitoring system would be amazing. It is like the "MATCH.COM" between the OT and the IT stakeholders. This would facilitate independent (unfiltered or manipulated) OEE data as well as a way for the OEM machine builders & control system integrator companies to always have up to the minute status of their assets under SLAs. Ultimately downtime is the devil and the devil is always in the details. For example an unnamed global automobile manufacturer that experiences a downtime event - on average costs them $30,000/minute. The mitigation and or facilitation of rapid MRO repsonse, would easily pay for the entire 3rd party and independent systems, even if it would save a minute or two a month 👀

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
We approach this solution by publishing the topic namespace of the OEMs assets to an upper level broker that they can access.  Rather than a separate solution for independent OEE and OEM Machine Status, we recommend publishing the pertinent topics in the namespace to a higher level for OEM and 3rd party access.  The engineering has already been done, just configure and transmit.

On the $30,000/minute downtime costs.  It is important to note that this is end of line downtime cost, not cost for any process with downstream surge capacity.  Great comments -- thank you!

Author: gyoung4659
Content: I'm getting challenged when wanting to establish a SCADA level to our shopfloor WRT report on exception. I'm being told that 5 axis CNC machines would pump out too much data and it would overload the system. A little green to PLCs and SCADA so I'm hoping for some help here

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Depending on what you're looking to do, that may be a bit much for something like that to handle.  What are you looking to do with the data anyways?  I usually find that's the best thing to start with, as it usually helps to determine what you need to get the job done.  Also, another method might be to bypass the SCADA systems altogether and just dump the raw data into a lake for use at a later time.  The PLC is going to be dedicated to the running of the actual machine, and the SCADA system is probably fairly structured, and monitoring a limited number of parameters.  An edge-type infrastructure, where you are sending everything to a central repository (local, cloud, etc.) via an edge connection is probably the best solution in this case.  Let the PLC and SCADA system operate as they are, and pull data from the machines through an edge connection for more in-depth/advanced analytics.  Lets the system run as designed, and still provides the more data intensive capabilities.  Walker did a good video on what that infrastructure would look like.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: https://youtu.be/0gd4CcZYo9s

Author: gyoung4659
Content:
End goal I want to establish a 4.0 IIoT, but currently we are looking to help set up a machine monitoring system for machine utilization and tooling costs. I was thinking to have a SCADA layer to structure the data from each CNC machine and structure it nicely to then be sent into a central data lake.

I guess I'm just confused as to a SCADA system vs. edge-type infrastructure. If a SCADA's role is to centralize and control data from many PLC's, wouldn't a UNS wanting raw PLC data need to be doing some kind of data structuring, essentially rendering a SCADA obsolete?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: The SCADA and the PLC are not going to be obsolete any time soon.  They are directly on the factory floor, while much of the edge infrastructure is going to be a little bit further out.  I see the edge infrastructure more as an enabler and an improvement tool rather than directly controlling the machine.  Yes, improvements in latency are going to mean that remote control will be possible, but I think that (at least at the moment), you would see advanced analytics providing input as to whether the programming within a PLC should be adjusted rather than directly controlling the machine.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Cnc machines are ridiculous data point generators! There’s easily tens of thousands of tags in some CNC controllers. I don’t get the objection to Report by exception though, and how it would cause more overload than any of the alternatives?

Author: gyoung4659
Content: Thanks Jon. The person I was discussing with was explaining that report by exception would essentially be grabbing all data at all times and we'd be better off grabbing snapshots every 60 seconds or so.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: SCADA is a set of tools to connect, visualize, monitor and control industrial processes at the supervisory level (area level or above), and specialized at this task so say. I don’t think they will be obsolete any time soon, unless they stop evolving to solve customers problems.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hmm.. A commonly stated factoid about PLCs is that less than 10% of PLC tags change more often than once per minute. You could do 1 second polling at the edge (edge gateway), and report by exception out. I’ve done 5k tags sampled between 10ms and 1 second with RBE on top (edge gateway), on a CNC controller and it’s not even making a dent in the network load. Leveraging Sparkplug B, report by exception and with compression.

Author: gyoung4659
Content: great to know. I'm trying to learn as much as I can here. Thanks for your input

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I don’t have all the details of your case, so this person may be right in what he’s saying, but his argument sounds like it could be made from a misunderstanding of how report by exception works.

Author: gyoung4659
Content: Of course, this was helpful though thank you.

Author: mparris
Content:
It may be the case that the CNC had a bunch of analog that is changing all the time, so report by exception doesn't make sense.

The gap in understanding could be not using an edge gateway to deadband those values before sending out, such as 1 value per minute or no change less than 0.01

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Which is the case in every conceivable CNC I can think of at least 😅 There is also an underlying sample rate to determine if the value has changed or not, such as gateway poll rate or controller cycle time. Isn’t doing RBE on top of any sampling always more efficient than polling at the same rate as the underlying sampling? The main missing piece here is why only poll at 60 second intervals? Are they polling over 56kBit modems here?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: In ThingWorx we had a couple options for damping (or not) signal state change notifications : any change, deadband as percentage of range, absolute deadband, and "never" (on-demand reads only).  We also implemented mechanisms to make "on-demand reads" more efficient.  In essence, you could define a cache strategy based on a "freshness date".  Thus, if 100 requestors ask for a property value within a certain amount of time, you might only make one request to the device/system, depending on cache expiration time.  I would also be thinking of RBE in both directions (from device -> IIoT platform/UNS and from there to consumers).  And in some cases you may want different policies for those.

Author: mparris
Content:
Those deadband functions seem in line with OPC-UA tactics, which is one thing they got right.

The filtering of on-demand requests sounds like a good federating function. Matrikon Data Broker looks to do the same with OPC-UA client/server connections: if there is one server and 100 clients with the same subscription needs (same tags only every 1000ms, for example), the one server would only see a single subscription from the federating application. It helps take the burden off the device to scale across the Enterprise.

Very similar to what a MQTT broker does for it's clients. Just need it in the request direction, as you point out

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Depending on model and firmware of Siemens PLC, the connectivity options will vary.  Older models will only have an S7 interface.  Newer models will have S7 and OPC-UA Server interfaces.  Newer models, with the right firmware, will have these and even an MQTT client interface.

Ignition SCADA is very popular in this community  If you don't like your old WinCC, you might like WinCC-OA.  Both of these solutions have interfaces for S7, OPC-UA, and MQTT.

As far as MQTT brokers, HiveMQ and EMQ are popular solutions.  Ignition offers an MQTT broker as a module.  It can be used with or without other Ignition SCADA modules.

Depending on your architecture and needs, you might find additional tools like KEPServerEX and HighByte helpful.  KEPServerEX can convert native protocols like S7 to OPC-UA or MQTT.  HighByte can help as a dedicated tool for modeling data going in and out of the MQTT broker.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Would you use Node Red instead of instead of say an Ignition Edge? Is that the purpose of most edge nodes near a PLC, to do an OPC to MQTT conversion?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'm not sure I would quite put it that way, but Node Red does make a lot of things "easy" because there are literally thousands of nodes to do all kinds of things. Only a handful are included in the default installation but it's supper easy to install what you need. For instance MQTT is usually included in the default install because pretty much everyone uses it for homebrew automation communications. Here's a screenshot of my "weather and office temp" nodes:

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You literally just "pipe" stuff together not unlike piping "|" in *nix platforms except instead of text you're piping messages with payloads.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: It also helps that companies like Opto 22 and Tulip have public nodes you can install. You don't just have to use it inside of an EPIC or Rio, as long as you're comfortable setting up keys/certs, you can run node red on another device but access the I/O or datastore of an EPIC or Rio remotely.

Author: ales7315
Content: Node-Red is a great tool. But has anybody used it in a production environment? It is used in gateways and PLCs (Opto 22), but I am not sure if I would use it as part of the infrastructure. Or I just don't know enough about it....

Author: andersgustav
Content:
I have.

I have been running what was originally a PoC for two years now as a simple SCADA system based on Node-RED, and it has worked very well.
The disadvantages are that it does not have user management for dashboards, nor dashboards that are easy to build for an industrial application (flow, pipes etc).

We're migrating to Ignition and Perspective these days, but I will not hesitate to use Node-RED for some tasks on the edge o.l. 
It is a Swiss army knife in IIoT, and I think we will see more and more vendors offer it in their solutions in the future.

*Also: Nick O'Leary has left IBM and is going full time pro with the Node-RED project in his new company FlowForge. So I won't be surprised if industrial strengthened products will appear in the future.*

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There are other companies doing production grade Node-Red also.

Author: andersgustav
Content: True, there are. But I (personal preference) kinda like to stick with the original, as I feel most comfortable with it. 😉

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'm cheering for Nick and team as well!

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yes, we use node red in two Opto 22 groov EPICs and 6 Rios and it has been rock solid. I haven't had to reboot the groovs or restart Node Red yet and it's been running for at least 6 months in production.

Author: hobbes1069

Author: justinb0044
Content:
Hi all,
I am new to Ignition and I am after some community support.
I have a transaction group that is executed on a trigger, storing time stamped metrics into a SQL data base.   I then have a  named query that returns the data set and is bound to a table.  However, the time stamp column returns a value in Unix time (see below), I am wanting to know how I can convert or transform the timestamp column to a more human readable date time format.  Has anyone else experienced this before?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Add a DATEADD function to the timestamp column in the select statement.  It should include parameter for seconds as the interval and the epoch time as the date.  This will convert to native datetime based on the number of seconds that have eclipsed since the arbitrary 1970 base date.  The syntax will vary based on your underlying database.  Check out SQL epoch time conversion tutorials for more details.  Here's an example below:
```DATEADD(S, t_stamp, '1970-01-01')```
This probably could also be accomplished through an expression or binding a property, but it's probably more efficient to leave heavy lifting to the database.  Additionally, it might be worthwhile to have the timestamp stored in the database's native datetime format rather than passing the raw timestamp as an integer.

I'm curious to hear how others would approach this.

Author: justinb0044
Content: Thanks! I'll try that and let you know how I go

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Can Ignition handle millisecond or nanosecond resolution timestamps natively?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, there actually are HUGE advantages to passing the raw timestamp as an integer.   For one, it's considerable smaller than the corresponding unicode string.  It also eliminates a TON of parsing and formatting on both ends, which is both computationally demanding and creates a lot of memory objects that might need garbage collection depend on what's on either end.  If the numeric representation is normalized to UTC than it makes life a whole lot easier.  One of the big flaws of using JSON for industrial data transfer relates to date/time or timestamp handling.  No consistent approach.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Oh, and TIME ZONES AND DAYLIGHT SAVINGS TIME SUCK!!!

Author: dundo6741
Content: https://xkcd.com/1883/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yes, there are date/time properties.  Anyways, in this case, it's more a function of Ignition bastardizing a relational database as a historian.  With a time series database, it would be a different story.  Because of the multiple columns, I thought @justinb0044 was merely making some sort of transactional report.  Usability was the basis of recommending the native datetime format.

I'm glad microsecond and nanosecond were brought up.  What I posted was not scaled.  Check out these support documents:
https://support.inductiveautomation.com/hc/en-us/articles/360047136252-Understanding-Tag-Historian-Timestamps
https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/fast-data-trending-with-millisecond-resolution/10724/5

The integer vs datetime discussion is interesting.  Relational database technology has evolved a lot in the past 10 years.  I wonder how much of it makes a difference in Ignition in the case.  It's sort of a moot point as most would conclude that it's preferable to leverage a proper time series database.

All things equal, integer is lighter weight and theoretically more performant.  But, with other factors (e.g., localization, daylights savings time, parameters, analytics) at play, normalizing to the database's native methodology for handling datetime typically pays off.  In contemporary databases, there often isn't a difference in performance.  There is a lot of clever tech under the hood for this.  And in some cases, with the all the features to support analytical workloads, datetime is actually more performant.  The real deciding factor comes down to usability.

You're right about the inconsistent handling.  It's honestly a problem everywhere.  I would argue it's even worse in the ERP world than industrial data transfer world.  If only we could all just embrace ISO 8601.

Author: billliu4646
Content: I used the underlying node.js libraries from Node-Red to build by own node application. Node projects using npm are very quick to deploy in docker containers. It practically take less than 1 seconds to make a change to the application. Javascript or Typescript code is also much more source control friendly compared to Node-Red's json files. Not to mention the ability to write unit tests with industry standard Javascript or Typescript test framesworks.

Microsoft is now focusing on .Net Core (now just called .Net) instead of legacy .Net Framework used by Factory Studio. Java is still actively being developed by the OpenJDK, Oracle and Azul...

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Does anyone know why Archestra/Wonderware uses SuiteLink communication protocol to communicate to PLC tags? I'm assuming SuiteLink is like OPC?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It doesn't - Suitelink is used between Wonderware and the I/O drivers.  The I/O driver uses whatever protocol the PLC supports.  SuiteLink was a replacement/evolution for NetDDE when Microsoft deprecated it.

Author: dzimmerman
Content: @DaveHellyer(Tatsoft) could you respond to this? Especially interested in the .net discussion

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'm interested as well. I don't currently have a preference between the two but I like the "theoretical" advantage of Tatsoft but I've also played around with Ignition and I very much like the admin interface, it seems more direct without all the visual bells & whistles of Factory Studio.

Author: andymellor
Content: It's worth taking a look at Tatsoft FactoryStudio. It has both OPC UA, classic and a native Siemens connector with some direct import capability from the Siemens s7-1500 PLC. MQTT out of the box and it's got some native connectors for things like OSIsoft PI - I believe that is a commonly used historian in the power industry.

Author: andymellor
Content: I'm not the best to explain the differences since I really do not know much about Ignition, but I've just been reviewing the Hub and spoke architecture of Ignition and I can't see any real difference between that and Tatsoft. Tatsoft has a concept of an Application Gateway that provides a secure way of integrating remote servers. This allows remote users to connect using a form of federated security model. There is also a simple remote tag server function and also a remote client server interface.  Tatsoft scales very well, some of the oil projects that they have case studies for are many millions of tags.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: And dynamic tags...

Author: benveenema
Content:
Everyone see this in the latest Ignition update post?
"Cache Your Check and Share with Your Friends
In Ignition 8.1.12, several Perspective bindings receive a new setting called “Shared and Cache.” This new feature consolidates multiple identical polling tasks that optimize data queries. When the setting is enabled, the query uses a polling engine that is shared across all running Perspective sessions. The polling engine will run the query once, cache the value, and deliver results to all registered users.

The new feature allows certain binding types to cache data from a source, such as a database query, and allow other session instances to use the same cached data. So instead of having each HMI session query data, multiple running sessions can share data from one database query.

The new settings are added to Tag History Bindings, Named Query Bindings, and HTTP Bindings as simple checkboxes. In addition, the Alarm Status Table component and the Alarm Journal Table component implement this functionality natively."

https://inductiveautomation.com/blog/ignition-8112-more-perspective-features-vision-updates-and-a-little-bit-more

Author: benveenema
Content: Seems pretty useful and like it borrows some of the idea from the UNS.

Author: i.am.pau
Content:
Hello, I am exploring different solutions for the following scenario. I have a series of facilities spread across the country:
* ~ 2000 facilities
* ~ 100 devices / facility
* ~ 100 signals / device (slow data. Like 1min poll rate)
* TOTAL = ~ 10M tags
* Each facility must have a small SCADA / HMI to monitor and control its devices (connected via Modbus). It is not necessary to have synoptics. It is only necessary to have alarms and notifications. Some alarms are managed by the SCADA, so it is necessary to be able to define the alarm logic (check conditions, timers, etc).
* Also, it's required to have a central SCADA to monitor all stores and orchestrate local scada changes. Information will be exchanged with local SCADAs through an MQTT broker.
* Each facility must be independent of the central scada. So if communication is lost, the local SCADA must continue to operate and store data (buffering).

I am looking at a WinCC OA based solution but the licenses are very (VERY) expensive. I am also considering Igntion but perhaps I have the same problem since I have seen that the licensing is per server and here we would have about 2000, right? Would the Ignition Edge be a right option to these needs?

I am also considering an open source service based solution. I have seen Libre but I don't know if it's mature enough.

Ideas outside of SCADA are welcome.

Thank you very much in advance!

Author: andymellor
Content: Tatsoft has built in modbus that works very well. Inter system security is excellent. We are looking at a similar requirement kn the UK. Pricing for Tatsoft is as good as you will get, especially at the edge. Speak to me in Europe or @DaveHellyer(Tatsoft) anywhere else.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: What type of facilities are you looking at?  This should have an impact on the solution that you are looking at.  With such a slow poll rate, it seems like these aren't critical or hazardous applications, but if there are regulations surrounding the collection and use of data, that would need to be taken into account when looking at this application.

Author: i.am.pau
Content: The devices are very varied but they aren't critical or hazardous.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The on-machine or "Edge" licensing of the modern SCADA / IIoT platforms are probably a good option.  

Another approach you could take is to work with sales teams to appropriately price their solution for your application.  There is no perfect pricing model.  Everyone derives value differently and there will be outliers.  Moving beyond merely plugging numbers into a CPQ engine could really pay off.  For example, a smaller site with advanced automation can have more tags than massive enterprise with many sites with basic automation.  In the end, pricing is about discriminating between firms who can afford to pay more and those who cannot.

I know no one likes downtime and it's not acceptable, but it is worthwhile assessing the likelihood and cost of downtime.  How has network downtime historically compared to utilities, material, or labor downtime?  There was a time when people scoffed at the cloud or shared services for non-industrial applications.  Eventually, the benefits outweighed the risks and architecture made it feasible.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: @Pau It doesn't sound like you need control capability, correct?  Slow data usually means monitoring only.

Author: i.am.pau
Content: It is mostly monitoring, but not only. There will be some minor control maneuvers (which are not time critical). For example: At a certain time send a command to turn off the lights (it doesn't matter if it's a minute later).

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: Can we talk offline?  I'd like to understand more.  The issue is the need for a local SCADA node at each site for resiliency.  Coming from a sales perspective, all of those local instances are typically chargeable unless you have some type of agreement that allows for unlimited use and a flexible architecture.  And there's table stakes for such an agreement.

Author: daveh7519
Content: @Bill Liu It really depends on what's important to you, and how soon you want to get to "bleeding edge" (they call it that for a reason 🙂),  When your application needs high performance, with reliability, like real-time factory floor server operations, or if your application needs high-end edge devices or advanced graphics and multithreaded calculation or analytics, the full .NET Framework is ***still*** the platform of choice for large Microsoft users and Fortune 500 companies.  It is a highly stable, mature, complete, and ***field-proven*** platform. FrameworX from Tatsoft is built on .NET and can outperform systems created with non-Microsoft technologies, that are dependent on Java.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I actually don't think this is necessarily a bad thing.  Subscriptions are not bad if they're providing value.  

I personally dislike Microsoft Outlook/Exchange.  It's exposed to the internet and it must be lifecycled.  Setting aside data governance or compliance issues, why not have it live there?  I don't believe the benefits of a full-featured client with a replicated database exceeds the cost of building and maintaining it.  Email is basically like a utility or commodity.  It's not differentiating.

It's not a black or white thing though.  For example, other applications that involve producing content benefit from a client.  Perhaps this would be less of an issue if they were architected like mobile applications?  It just seems more fragile than it should be.

Author: waterworldwasok0842
Content: I am currently in the process of trying to create an ignition dashboard that is subscribed to an MQTT broker that is publishing real time data. I am able to subscribe to the broker using the MQTT engine module, but the tags that are published from the MQTT broker never update and I only see the data that was published when I first subscribed. Using MQTT explorer I can see that the broker is constantly publishing new data and I am not sure why in ignition I am not able to see the latest data points. Does anyone have an idea of how what configurations I need from MQTT engine to get the latest published data?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Flat MQTT or Sparkplug? The latter updates automatically. If the former, how are you parsing the payload?

Author: andersgustav
Content:
Should update automatically both flat and SpB.
Does the metric change?

Cause, if the evnt produces a equal value as previous event, Ignition will not change the tag. (No point in repeating what have not changed)

Author: waterworldwasok0842
Content: @DavidSchultz I chose to parse the payload as JSON. Removing that option now has ignition picking up the changes. Thank you both @DavidSchultz and @Anders Gustav!

Author: andersgustav
Content:
Nice :)

Do you have a json payload? If so, Ignition can't handle multilevel/nested json arrays, så it has to be Objects.
Then you can tick of the parse as json option.

When doing that, Ignition actually is pretty cleaver, and you can publish full tag model on birth, and Then update only the Keys affected by the event.

Author: justinb0044
Content:
Hi all,
I am seeking guidance from the Ignition experts in the community. I am wanting to know the best way to use UDTs with MQTT.
My use case involves an Ignition sever hosted in the cloud with a Mapple Systems smart gateway on the edge publishing's PLC data to the Ignition sever over spark plug b. When I try to define a UDT under the MQTT engine tag provider I receive an error, which leads me to believe I cannot use UDTs under the MQTT tag provider.
Am I better or defining a UDT under the the default tag provider and using reference tags or am I better off using Ignition Edge to define the UDT on the edge and publish up to the cloud?
Is there any way to use UDTs under the MQTT tag provider or am I missing something?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Your requirements sound like a perfect fit for Libre. We can run a local instance at each site without a license fee, and a central system to bring everything together. The local SCADA UI could be Grafana with some of our custom panels, or a mobile app if a mobile user experience would be preferred.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The UDTs in the mqtt tag provider will populate with the UDTs that is received at birth from Sparkplug B nodes. So if you define templates (UDT) at the edge, it will appear on the MQTT tag provider UDT automatically. Wether it’s better to define the UDTs at the edge or using references at the SCADA-level will depend. There are advantages to both. I’ve heard “best practices” that argue for each. Define as close to the source (edge) as possible, and also to leave source as is and build models/UDTs at higher levels.

Author: mparris
Content:
I've never tried using Sparkplug Templates with ignition mqtt Engine, but what @Jon Forbord stated would have been my guess.

Just like you can't define tags in the MQTT Engine tag provider, you shouldn't be able to define UDTs. It's all defined by the publisher (edge driven)

Author: justinb0044
Content: @Jon Forbord @MParris Thanks for the guidance.  I have since found out that the Mapple Systems smart gateway doesn't allow for UDTs to be built on the edge, so I will have to do it at the SCADA layer.  However, if I was to use Ignition Edge then I would be able to define the UDT on the edge and have it propagate to the cloud.

Author: almukhtar
Content: Check Arlen Nipper demo he did with cfemedia basically he took the udt from edge to aws sitewise,  for me this demo was enlightening

Author: rickbullotta
Content: To me that’s where the huge fail happens. That assumes that the publisher understands the context you want in your UNS, which it rarely does. Device data is just a piece of the puzzle.  Even structured data from SPb or OPC or whatever needs to be “reshaped” and combined into a more meaningful namespace doesn’t it?

Author: mparris
Content:
I don't think so, but if course it depends.

I'm envisioning a machine integrator not asking what its IP Address should be, but instead asking where it should publish its data. It will be a while until we get there...

Ideally, the machine's data would already implement the model for that machine as defined by the end-user. So it can publish its data within a "machine object" framework or template.

Within the UNS, other, higher-level applications can be notified on new machine objects being added, and perform aggregating functions such as adding up the part counts from all the machines. Since the aggregating function knows what part of the business it is interested in, and that it is only concerned with machines, it can filter against only machine objects within that location.

If the data being published is just a sensor value, for example, then templates don't make sense.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Yes, I would think so, at least in most brownfield projects. UDTs from the edge will be incomplete for some cases if you don’t consume data from the other layers. Such as BOM id, maintenance data etc. Some of it could definitely be populated from the edge in a greenfield project, rather than defined at other layers. My thinking now is that it will need to be different layers of UDTs/models. But it’s a work in progress and I keep modifying my approach as I learn more on the consumption side.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Problem is that only some of the "machine data" comes from the machine. 😉

Interesting to see you and Jon disagree on this, not surprised at all.  There are definitely some cases where symmetry between the "device" and its digital representation at the app level are common - more in "classic" IoT use cases where you have a fleet of identical or nearly identical machines/devices/assets.  Much less common in manufacturing use cases, where "identical" is an outlier.

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm coming from the "identical" use-case you mentioned, where the machine software is under control as well as the consuming application.  So having the software define the model where updates to that software at the same time improves the model, then the consuming application simply receives those updates and inherently understands the additional data.  For the user that owns both sides, this is most efficient.

For systems that aren't so strongly typed, or disparate, or brownfield, then a middleman is required, where any change in data on the floor drives an update in at least three locations: (1) device makes a new datapoint available, (2) dataops incorporates this within the larger model, (3) application is modified/created to utilize the data.

I think that explains the disagreement. 😆

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The big theme here is commonality.  Absence commonality, it seems like everything will need to run through DataOps.

I was just thinking about this the other day.  I wondered if greenfield nodes could ever hit the broker natively.  Increasingly, I don't know if dataops could ever be bypassed.  I generally work with fairly new automation, but almost nothing meets the 'minimum technical requirements'.  It's lower cost and practical to retrofit/integrate internally than it is to firmly demand it as a requirement in my industry.  It's easier to specify "create this UDT for a fieldbus node to produce and consume tags to" as a foundation to build on than try to do anything more.  Due to launch complexities (e.g., capital constraints, slow customer authorizations, engineering changes), machines are barely ready when they're received.  As a result, the integration must be agile.  The only constant is change.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I think what I meant was "progressive web app"
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Progressive_web_apps
Progressive web apps are web apps with some additional information that lets your browser create a more native app experience.
The app has it's own icon and launches separately from the browser. Gmail and OnShape are two examples that use regularly, but lots of website use them as well. https://progressivewebapp.store/

If a Perspective project could present as a PWA, it would give a more native experience for users on an Andriod, iOS, or MS tablet device.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Hey peeps! Anyone here who's implemented high speed telemetry with Ignition? It will arrive as arrays of buffered data with values and timestamps down to milliisecond. I'm particularly wondering how to ensure that Ignition stores the history with the right timestamps. I see from the documentation it may be possible using fully qualified values for your system.tag.writeBlocking, but I'm wondering if there's a direct way to format the TCP payload to make this happen natively.

Author: du5tins
Content: Quick question on Ignition... do people tend to stick with one version or use whatever is available at the time? We are deploying some edge gateways from Opto22 and Moxa for a customer and I was curious about that. Do we just worry about keeping the same major version? Or is it best practice to also match up minor versions?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Dustin Symes, you just advanced to level 4!

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Replying to my own post in case others are wondering. For this particular case, there is no native way to get timestamps attached through the TCP driver. The payloads will need to be parsed through a script and use tag.storeTagHistory or tag.writeBlocking with a fully qualified value. tag.storeTagHistory is the recommended way.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: All depends on how you are using Ignition. It is not just the version of Ignition but the version of the module and subsequent features.

Author: du5tins
Content: Thanks David. The intent is to publish into a central broker with SPB so that should decouple us enough that the version doesn’t matter too much.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: SCADA systems can certainly be installed in a cloud/datacenter, whether running on a VM or natively. The challenge becomes running the underlying plant upon loss of connectivity. Around release 8.1.8 of Ignition, it supports a failover architecture that if the cloud connectivity is lost, a local instance will assume control. 4IR uses this for their cloud MES offering running on a local Opto 22 groov EPIC.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Obviously Opto 22 uses it a lot, it's also on all the Tulip hardware, but it's purpose is to allow you to "glue" things together. So from an IoT/Edge device  point of view you could say it scales, but you typically wouldn't have it on a centralized server handling a ton of connections. For one, it's single threaded so no matter how many virtual cores you throw at it, you're only going to get so much performance. You can run multiple instances, but that can quickly get out of hand as well.

Author: themetaboy
Content: Hi, do you know any SCADA solution that can connect with ANY PLC ?

Content: Wonderware of course.

Author: themetaboy

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Most SCADA solutions can connect to any PLC either directly or indirectly.  Directly refers to a SCADA having a driver for a PLC's native protocol.  Tatsoft and Wonderware have among the largest driver suites.  Most other SCADA products will focus on having drivers that support the PLCs with the largest market share (e.g., Siemens, AB, Mitsubishi, Modbus, Omron).  Indirectly refers to the SCADA connecting up to a third-party solution such as an OPC Server or gateway.  In conclusion, sometimes the SCADA connect to the PLC natively (e.g., S7, EtherNet/IP) and sometimes they connect to a gateway over a normalized IIoT protocol (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA).

Here are some some architectures that will satisfy connectivity to most PLCs without IIoT protocol support..

[SCADA] [Native Driver] <- native protocol -> [PLC]

[SCADA][OPC-UA Client] <- OPC-UA -> [OPC-UA Server][Native Driver] <- native protocol -> [PLC]

[SCADA][MQTT Client] <- MQTT -> [Broker] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Client][Gateway][Native Driver] <- native protocol -> [PLC]

[SCADA][MQTT Client] <- MQTT -> [Broker] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Client][Gateway][OPC-UA Client] <- OPC-UA -> [OPC-UA Server][Native Driver] <- native protocol -> [PLC]

SCADA solutions with native drivers
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC80/OPC+UA+Drivers
https://tatsoft.com/drivers-and-protocols/
https://www.aveva.com/en/products/communication-drivers/
https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/mdm/102691766?c=68380112011&lc=en-US
https://iconics.com/Products/OPC-Connectivity/DeviceXplorer-OPC-Server

Drivers supported by OPC Server / Connectivity Suites
https://www.kepware.com/en-us/products/kepserverex/suites/manufacturing-suite/#pnlComponentDrivers
https://www.matrikonopc.com/drivers/plcs.aspx
https://litmus.io/litmus-edge/supported-devices/
https://docs.devicewise.com/Content/Products/GatewayDevelopersGuide/Devices/DeviceTypes/Device-types.htm#:~:text=deviceWISE%20contains%20rich%20library%20of,Omron%20driver%2C%20and%20Beckhoff%20driver.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Are you using switching that support Precision Time Protocol (aka IEEE 1588 PTP)?  This is sometimes marketed as CIP Sync or CIP Motion on the Stratix products.  Unfortunately, they offer products with different firmware versions with and without this.  This technology enables determinism and motion control for EtherNet/IP.

If I recall, for anything with motion instructions (e.g., PF527, Kinetix), it's advised to have managed switch with PTP or connect directly to the processor.  Also, check that the ports have the appropriate QoS tags assigned.  Outside of the IOS CLI, the GUI has something some sort of device type for each port that (I believe) should do this.  While different CIP class traffic has a default priority order, it becomes ambigueous with enough nodes and when nothing is defined.  This tends gets overlooked because it's not really a thing with other fieldbuses and, with EtherNet/IP, it's not a problem until it's a problem.

Also, check the Requested Packet Interval (RPI) on the connections.  Some of the default settings can be too aggressive for the application and processor.

Author: johndevenney
Content: Thanks for the input, CIP Sync is not use I believe. right now there is an unmanaged switch that only has connections to other devices as part of the machine. I will be traveling to look at the machines again and am going to look at it a lot closer.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah.  It's buggy and they take a long time to boot.  Some models with some firmware are so buggy that they overwork the processor and have tendancy to look up.  The only way to recover them is flash with a new image over TFTP.

The economics aren't very good either.  It costs a fortune to add layer 3, full-featured firmware, PoE, and additional ports.  I get that it's a rugged unit with redundant power supplies, but it's older technology and the numbers don't add up.  Some of the higher-end Stratix models cost a significant fraction of what some Catalyst models do.  Think advanced access or even distribution workloads (e.g., 24/48 ports, 10G uplinks, stacking, PoE, integrated wireless control, orchestration, security).

I do love the idea of the product.  Having an "OT" interface (e.g., Browser GUI, Studio 5000) on an IOS/XE switch is smart.  It's machine builder friendly while being very interoperable with everything else on most end-user networks.  The software is just so bloated that it's not worth it in many cases.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
IT infrastructure team would perfer us not to host our own servers, instead put our equipment OPCs server in a data center 100's of miles away. 
Can we relaiblity get data from say a ControlLogix PLC that way?

Or have some sort of hardware local that can talk natively to ~ 50 PLCs, then serve up the data for MES to consume. (OPC UA, SpB, .....)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I probably wouldn't be communicating directly with my PLCs from the remote DC.  I'd put the OPC servers locally, and then get the data to a UNS/MQTT broker/Unicorn in the DC.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Yeah that's the feedback I've been getting pretty much from everywhere. 
Now what's preferred method to run the OPC servers, traditional server rack mounted hosting VMs or something more like a smaller IIoT gateway device? It would be talking to about 50 PLCs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: How will you be communicating with the PLCs? Ethernet? Serial? Proprietary network/cable?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Do you have a climate and access controlled room on or near the shop floor?

Author: mriiot
Content: Are all 50 Ethernet I/p capable?  How many tags per PLC?

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
The answer is no for a server room. 

Probably the reason they went with the Telit DeviceWise IIoT appliances about 10 years ago on each line. Current those devices already connect to all the PLC and Labview cRIOs (Ethernet) and send the data offsite to a regional data center database. 

Why when a new MES comes to town it thinks it will get its own servers with a climate controlled room to poll away at the controllers, … wrong!. 

Maybe the best option (and more cost effective) is to leverage the existing IIoT appliances and have MES connect to a HighByte/HiveMQ.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
I always get confused here. What would I call a product that connects to PLCs via its native protocol and the serves up the data? I just say OPC sever out of habit. 

I don’t need it to be OPC, just something the MES can consume. (And other stuff)

Author: mparris
Content:
Ahh, that clarifies it.

In the technical sense, an OPC server is simply an application that can receive connection requests from OPC Clients to exchange data. A Windows application that is simply a random number generator could contain an OPC Server.

I've also heard the term OPC Server to refer to applications like Kepware or Matrikon that have a swiss-army knife of drivers to connect to southbound devices and serve up am OPC server. Then after more advanced, they added other communication protocols, but the "OPC Server" name stuck. Today, I would refer to these as Data Aggregators, Data Federators, or Data Gateways

@Walker Reynolds referred to OPC servers not being report-by-exception because of the inefficiencies of the device drivers having to poll in blocks of data at a time, instead of getting each register separately.

It confused me for a while until I finally understood what he meant by OPC server 😆

The DataCommander "DC" (will put link below) is the device that talks to the PLC directly. (that is currently working in production today) It talks to Control/CompactLogix, Labview cRIOs. 
There's some flexiblity in the DC's to write logic, so current logic is to read PLC tags, then take the results and do a SQL insert into a regional data center. The DC's have some store/forward capabilites as well.

Both HighByte/HiveMQ are new to me so need to do some homework to see if it's possible the DC's can work with a HighByte/HiveMQ UNS.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Actually the deprecated DC's that are running do support MQTT but when talking to some folks who have looked into it, they think the MQTT support was an afterthough in the software development of the product. (they mentioned it supported flat MQTT non-secure, but not MQTT via TLS) Those DC's I think are really designed for store & forward to SQL. Overall it still might be possible to cobble together an MQTT message out of the DC's, it might not be the hardened solution we want for the long term.

Another possibility if we don't want/trust to the DC's to do the MQTT conversion, then have the DC's write to a local SQL DB, then do a HighByte to MQTT ??

Final idea if we want to introduce new hardware / start phasing out the old DC's, maybe we can get rugged industrial style PC's running Ignition Edge that run along side the existing DCs. Then we can keep the old stuff running and slowly transistion over to the Ignition world...

Much to ponder, LOL.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: IMO dumping data into a SQL database, while technically simple, creates a fragile and tightly coupled integration layer and UNS.  The moment you have to start authoring SQL stored procedures attached to DB triggers to achieve your goals (which should include an event-driven architecture), something is suboptimal.  Just my $0.02.

Author: cyberwrights
Content: I'm working with a plant where 95% of the controllers are Siemens and they want to install Ignition Edge on-prem with the main Ignition gateway on the cloud. I have a local controls engineer trying to sell them Kepware in addition. If I have Ignition and all Siemens hardware, why do I need/want Kepware in the stack?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: I would say yes to “want”. Kepware’s Siemens drivers are superior to Ignition’s. If you’re running relatively new S7 processors and firmware, these support tag browsing and generation over the native protocol. Last I checked, Ignition’s drivers did not support this. Kepware’s drivers do. This is an extremely useful feature. Without it, one needs to know the details of the memory tables (e.g., tags, registers, address, data type) on the PLCs. Being able to point to a UDT on a PLC and have tags automatically built out for the IIoT infrastructure is great.

Author: cyberwrights
Content: Okay, that is information that obviously doesn't exist on Ignition's glossy PDFs, and I see there is a functional advantage so this guy has justification for his request. Would it be stoopid to run them (Kepware and Ignition Edge) on the same device, or best to have dedicated hardware for each?

Author: ctown_kyle
Content:
Thought experiment: Does it count as a recipe if it's hard-coded in a PLC?

I inherited some equipment at my new job that was only going to run one product and one product only. You can guess the next part. I've been asked to add more recipes only to find that the "recipes" are hard coded PLC tags.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not that uncommon, even with multiple "recipes".  I've even seen a rotary "recipe selector switch" on equipment!

Author: ryanthompson9142
Content:
I agree with this.  I have seen Ignition's drivers act slow and be non-responsive with Siemens and we have installed Kepware as a remediation.  Even knowing all of the data block addresses, sometimes there would just be errors where tag changes would be missed or writes would fail.  Installing Kepware fixed all of this. 

Kepware was installed on a separate device to support gateway redundancy, but had no issues running on the gateway.

Also note Ignition Edge has the pesky 2-device maximum (you can add on I think at $100/device).  If you had Kepware you could connect Kepware to as many devices as you wanted and then in Ignition edge it would only count as 1...

Author: cyberwrights

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It depends on the scale and network.  It could get quite costly if you have hundreds of assets that you intend to locally deploy Ignition Edge and Kepware on.  Kepware, ignoring the Linux-based "Edge" version, will need Windows licensing and hardware that can support it as well.  

Additionally, what is optimal will depend on what you consider to be "edge of network".  Do you have a lots of geographically distributed, smaller plants or remote assets with a constrained network?  Or do you have larger plants with lots of assets, performant LANs, and spare server compute?  In other words, is there a significant difference between demarcating "edge of network" in an asset's electrical panel or on a VM on a server on site?

If you need to scale up, it can make sense to have regular Ignition gateway paired with Kepware to provide connectivity and SCADA for various assets at a plant-level, area-level, or even line-level.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Haven’t used Kepware to know for sure about store & forward. Obviously I think Ignition Edge to Gateway store & forward would be solid , Kepware says 

“KEPServerEX can also store information in any ODBC-compliant database using the DataLogger advanced plug-in, which has a store-and-forward capability for when a database is unreachable or unable to process the information fast enough.”

Would Ignition Gateway play nice with Kepware data logger plug-in ?

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Does Kepware EX see Ignition Gateway as a database?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
DataLogger is basically like a SQL-based historian for KEPServerEx.  It's "store-and-forward" functionality acts as buffer in the event that ODBC connection to the SQL database goes down.  In other words, KEPServerEx DataLogger is a SQL client with a buffer.  The buffer queues up INSERT statements and writes them to disk until the database becomes accessible again.

Similarly, Ignition has its own SQL-based tag historian as well as the SQL bridge for transaction groups.  Both of these have "store-and-forward" capability to buffer the transactions in the event that the database is unavailable.  Like, KEPServerEx, Ignition is a SQL client with a buffer.

The above scenarios primarily relate to error-handling of SQL connections.  They do not address the resiliency of general tag or data access.  

In most architectures, Ignition sees KEPServerEx as a OPC-UA Server.  OPC-UA connections have quality and other meta data that can indicate when there is an issue with a connection.  Kepware with the IoT Gateway has some buffering with MQTT interface and more sophisticated store-and-forward with the AlwaysOn protocol interface for ThingWorx.

It would be helpful to know more about your architecture and where you're concerned about having store-and-forward.  For example, are you trying to have remote assets or plants interface with a central Ignition gateway across a WAN that may be subject to connection issues?

Here are a few different scenarios of working with native protocols and various software gateways.  Typically, one would setup MQTT client to reside at the edge of the network before connections can degrade.

[PLC] <- native protocol -> [KEPServerEx] <- OPC-UA -> [Ignition/Edge] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Broker]
[PLC] <- native protocol -> [KEPServerEx with IoT Gateway] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Broker]
[PLC] <- native protocol -> [Ignition/Edge] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Broker]
[PLC] <- native protocol -> [KEPServerEx] <- OPC-UA -> [HighByte] <- MQTT -> [MQTT Broker]

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Are you using the full Google Manufacturing Data Engine (MDE)?  If so you should be able to make use of the Manufacturing Connect and Manufacturing Connect Edge (MC and MCe respectively) to handle your device connection and send out the local information to your local people (i.e. display line status to an Andon board).  MCe can send data from the local sources to the local displays, or can even take data from a central source and display it locally.  MC is going to be your central point of control for the organization where you can manage the deployed instances from a central point.  Full disclosure, I work for Litmus, who developed the MC and MCe platforms.

Content: my thinking was to have a few Grafana Nodes in Node-Red similar in function to the current Node-Red Nodes that get installed under Node-Red Dashboard, basically adding more fancy charts to the current Node-Red visualisation (Dashboard) capabilities...

Author: plcmercenary
Content: @NickN I understand what you are driving at. I have been developing on Node-Red for a while now and before we mapped out the recent 3.0 node red release earlier this year I had a discussion with Steve McL and Nick about the path forward with the dashboard nodes.

Author: plcmercenary
Content:
@NickN so the crux of the Node-Red-Dashboard nodes is their reliance on mustache templating and the template node / node_mustache functionality underpinning a couple other dependencies 

Dashboard was constructed modularly  and encapsulated web components because of Angular (1) framework
Angular(1) is EOL and will only be a backport package for another couple years
Angular2 is a hard breaking change from angular1 and radically changed the template node and mustache execution limiting the scope of what is even possible  in this context

Author: plcmercenary
Content: @NickN So there isnt a real clear path forward since it is a non trivial effort to rebuild dashboard in another framework only to be here again. there are a TON of dashboard nodes that are unmaintained and still work on the pinned version of NR-Dash, Updating all of the nodes that are in the wild.. its not an easy answer

Author: plcmercenary
Content: Its also somewhat daunting to consider that modular web components are  a function of the front end framework, React and Angular are both owned by Facebook and Google respectively and vue is a community framework. There is no promise of longevity unless we are going fork vue and roll our own JS Framework. for dashboard

Author: plcmercenary
Content:
So with that said there are a couple avenues worth pursuing. 

1) Grafana charts can be configured to be embedded. They Iframe into a Node Red a dash nicely - not super dynamic or flexiable once created but functional

2) Custom CSS. Any dashboard node has CSS Classes, and arbitrary CSS can be dynamically applied with templates and with a little bit of workmanship can be really slick visually.   I think this is a really good thing to pursue. 

3) UI Builder. Implements ANY framework or no framework at all. and just executes the front end with a solid structure and template method to pass JS variables to the front end and messages back into the back end from events on the front end

Author: plcmercenary
Content: There is more - afk for 5

Author: plcmercenary

Author: josh_earnest
Content: Is there a simulation software for #OPC ?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Depends on what you mean by simulate and what OPC functionality.

If you're looking to simulate connections and tags in a typical implementation (i.e., TCP Binary Data Access), you could use Kepware.  To simulate a server, you could leverage the simulation drivers (e.g., fixed values, ramp) for the tags.  Client side, it could connect to another server.

If your use cases is more on debugging/analyzing a connection, look into Unified Automation's products.  UaExpert is a "go-to" client for testing.

If you're looking to simulate a factory with OPC connections, you could look into something like Factory I/O.  This has an OPC UA interface

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's not a "device" problem that's a "software design" and "user experience" problem.  You want to architect your systems such that users primarily see what requires their attention, but can easily navigate to any monitoring or investigational displays/tools quickly.

Author: jameswise8829
Content:
Not sure if this is the best channel to ask this but…. Does anyone have a suggestion on downtime entry platform in cases where additional operator input is required? I would like status to be automatic as much as possible, however we have some cases (e.g. stop button pressed) where we want the operator to select from a list of groups and reasons in that group. I feel like this could be at the MES level but we aren’t there yet. We had a proposal to modify the HMI and control system for this. However, this isn’t my first choice because I’d rather try and identify a more “generic” solution. We have a lot of different PLCs and related software. While there are other features I’d like, some key ones right now are:
1)    Ability to prevent a machine from starting if no downtime reason was entered. This is where I think control system integration will be required on some level but again would like to go as “generic” as possible. For this, I thought about possibly writing a program and having all our control systems written so that the declaration entry system could activate a PLC input to inhibit running. Even better might be some small piece of hardware we could add like a relay to prevent running so that we don’t have to make any changes. 
2)     Be able to handle the entered reason retroactively. For example, machine state goes to stopped/not producing at 8:00, reason entered at 8:05, machine starts producing at 8:07, would like all 7 minutes of that single stop instance to be associated with the reason they entered.

Author: IIoT#4707

Author: oculus5986
Content: This really depends on the content the operators are viewing.  Solutions exist to track the mouse and also unify all mice and keyboards into one set for multiple workstations.  The source systems can be engineered to display the most important information when required.  Another way of reducing stress for the operator is by introducing a large display / 'personal videowall' for each operator and then implement layouts and dashboards to bring relevant/important information to him.  Camera's can also be embedded into some of the other displays to reduce number of physical displays.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
In my experience, the *LAST* thing an operator wants to be doing while or even after a downtime event is to be entering data into a system.  Particularly during.  I would also challenge you to question the value of collecting the granular downtime data forever.  Have a process or manufacturing engineer spend a few days in the plant and talk to the operators, watch the machines, etc...you'll get a good sense of what is causing issues from that.

I've probably done 100+ downtime capture systems over the years . What was funny was how, particularly with long lists of downtime codes, the operator usually picked the top one or one near the top of the list.  When we noticed that, we decided to randomize the order of the list.  Lo and behold, downtime reasons started to become uniformly distributed across all the options in the list.  Point being that the information may not be as accurate as you'd think or of much value versus actually spending time on the plant floor and talking to the people who deal with the downtime issues on a daily basis.

Author: nickn5549
Content: keep the list short and double check (automatically) with the data captured in CMMS - worked done on the machines - in this way you can isolate the 'bad apples'

Author: cmc4010
Content:
Hi, (Q1) can anyone recommend SCADA systems that are cheaper than Ignition? I'm aware that Ignition is very popular in the community, but I'm looking for cheaper alternatives that are just as good? The number of tags used in my factory does not exceed 1000 tags.

Systems I want to monitor and log run time data:
- Industrial ovens (39 units)
- Production lines (mostly just conveyors)
- Cold storage
- Boilers
- Small wastewater treatment system

(Q2) Siemens WinCC Unified SCADA licenses appear to be cheaper for my use case, but what are its shortcomings compared to Ignition? WinCC doesn't seem to be talked about much.

The sales mentioned that these licenses would need to be purchased for WinCC Unified SCADA (not sure if it's missing any that I'm not aware of)

- Engineering
- Runtime
- Client (Operate)
- Client (Monitor)
- Database Storage

(Q3) How does WinCC Unified SCADA compare with the Ignition Unlimited Package: Basic? It seems like the Ignition Pro package is quite necessary for SQL bridge, Reporting, and Alarm modules, which increases the price tag by a lot. Does WinCC licenses have these "Pro" features by default?

Any input is appreciated

Author: jon.forbord
Content: It’s definitely not Citect and iFix. Ignition is my current preferred platform, primarily because you can almost do whatever the hell you want, and it fits well in a UNS architecture. SCADA is software-wise very similar to HMI, but usually is more limited in functionality or is bundled with some hardware with a touchscreen or buttons and a screen. My goto-layman’s explanation is that “SCADA is HMI on steroids”, or “SCADA is designed to do what an HMI does at the line or machine-level, but on the plant-level”.

Also the pricing seems very convoluted as usual, wrapped in a pay-for-what-you-use marketing message.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Does anyone here formally use the Alarms & Events (aka Alarms & Conditions) as prescribed by OPC or something standard in a similar fashion?

Or, are using whatever native alarm facilities come in your PLC and SCADA solutions?

Or, are you winging it?  Have you adopted some informal convention someone took when the PLCs were programmed?

Have you made an efforts to normalize alarming across the enterprise?  How has this gone?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Wish I had a good answer. Since we're 95% a CNC house and of those about 85% Fanuc, I just use KepserverEX to monitor for an alarmed state.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: So just whether there are any alarms native, but not necessarily the specific alarms?

Author: dvy___
Content: A lot of information online from the process industry side. Take a look at ISA 18.2.

Author: dvy___
Content: @Walker Reynolds mentioned something interesting in one of the latest podcasts about capturing every event. I didn't catch the details though. We have a customer who found an interesting solution to just send everything to Splunk, normally used to monitor IT systems.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Currently just the state, but FOCAS2 does give you the ability to pull the actual alarm (I believe up to 10 deep).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Nice.  I'm envious.  May I ask what CNCs you're working with?

A lot of Fanuc-based CNCs I've worked with have their own custom alarm implementation.  In many cases, they reside in the "C Language Executor" runtime.  These memory objects aren't always exposed over FOCAS.  They have to be written to registers accessible to Ladder engine to be picked up.

Long story short:  many things I've learned about Fanuc as CNC platform are not applicable to most of the machines I've worked with.  It seems like most machine builders seem to have their own bespoke implementations.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That's probably true, they definitely have their customizations, but as long as they give me the address I can read those registers as well. For the Makino Mills we have to read a custom memory address to interpret feedrate override. So I should have said, FOCAS2 supports reading the alarm codes, but I haven't actually tried to do it yet :).

Author: asthomas
Content: Cogent DataHub has a full-featured demo that runs for an hour at a time.  It contains a scripting language that can generate simulation data, as well as a couple of really simple data generators that just work out of the box.  The data is published as DA, UA, ODBC, Modbus, DDE, etc., so you can connect it to most software out there.  If you don't mind it conking out every hour then you can use it for testing and learning for free.

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: I've used SCADA systems for data acquisition but has anyone implemented the "Supervisory Control" aspect of SCADA? In my case, we have an inspection and packaging line with 7 pieces of equipment in series. Right now each machine "communicates" to upstream and downstream equipment using "ready to run" or "running" types of signals. I'm wondering if/how a full SCADA implementation can be beneficial here.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Recipe and process management, unified KPIs, coordination with other systems that are not hardwired or otherwise already integrated (e.g. RFID readers, weigh scales, etc), integration with ERP, etc...

Author: thunt.career
Content:
I typically use HMI to refer to either a standalone view terminal such as a PanelView or a single individual monitor/station within a distributed view application. I may refer to SCADA as the either the entirety of or specifically the server side components of a distributed application. Most software can perform SCADA regardless of type. I've made PanelView applications that run recipe management and execute track and trace functions for inventory and work order management.

What challenges are you facing? Is there line level logic that could simplify things? Are there 7 unique HMI terminals? Some use cases could be verifying and visualization that all machines are setup for correct or same product, downtime tracking by line and alerting operator on machine 7 that machine 1 is down, advanced user controls (this was technically PLC code, CIP Data Table Read Messages, but it wouldn't allow a user to login to a machine if they were logged into other specific machines on the line).

Author: asthomas
Content: Cogent DataHub has a built-in scripting engine that lets you produce any synthetic tags you like.  We have helped customers with scripts for sliding window and bucket aggregation.  Triggers for scripts can be data changes or timers, so you can do both.  Some other scripting examples include automatic start and stop of wind turbines due to ice, and due to EPA requirements surrounding the feeding habits of endangered bat species.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Quick poll: to connect to PLC and other mainstream devices/controllers, how many of you use native drivers provided by your SCADA vendor vs OPC vs OPC UA?  I'm finding a surprisingly small percentage using OPC UA in my informal polls elsewhere.  Would love to hear what this group is doing.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I have mainly used native drivers. The thought was to use the built in tools until there was a reason not to. 

Most of my SCADA experience is in Ignition though (as far back as 7.2).
I have never tried a non Allen Bradley PLC in FactoryTalk View (or VIew32) but I consider FactoryTalk View a PC based HMI rather than a SCADA platform.
The few iFix systems I have worked on had Kepware for PLC communication but those were set up by others (Up to a decade prior to my involvement).
I have not used Wonderware or WinnCC beyond serviec call level work so have never looked into connecting devices.

To date I really haven't had a need to stray from the built in drivers, and outside of Allen Bradley PLCs never really had to dig deep into the protocols themselves.
So I might not be the best one to answer this...

Author: _dyland
Content: Though, I do want to ask. Is there a reason we should be considering OPC ofer the native drivers? What is the drive behind this poll?

Author: aklein

Author: rickbullotta

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Normally native Drivers. Similarly to @Dylan DuFresne use the built in tools until there is no reason not too. 
Mostly the SCADA I have worked with in InTouch and System Platform. And normally connecting to Siemens and Allen Bradley PLC.
And the Wonderware/Aveva drivers I have found very robust.
I found AB very poor for OPC, Siemens a bit Better.
from what I can see B&R and Beckhoff were better. 
But normally where OPC came in to my designs were connecting to OEM controllers( e.g. Windfarm controller) or to L3 systems.

If I take the last Plant that was workign at, There is a collection of devices of different ages, some up to 20 years old. So for those I would have had to use the native driver. So it becomes much simpler to just stick with one.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Your question is very broad and hard to answer
Best places to Start
1 - Ask Chat GPT - tell it what you know and ask it to be a senior SCADA engineer, and explain what a SCADA does, and then keep askign it to define terms and andser questions.
2- Ask your System Integrator / Automation Engineers
3 - Ask your SCADA Vendor - they may have existing courses
4 - you Tube, lots of great resources out there.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
When I have encountered devices with embedded OPC UA servers, there were two main scenarios:

1) The machine builder shipped with super old firmware that did not have the OPC UA Server feature or there were bugs/limitations.  Upgrading the firmware wasn't worth the hassle unless there were a plan and resources available to overhaul the program for other reasons.

2) The implementation of OPC UA was so clunky and had myriad limitations.  It required launching PLC IDE software (sometimes at least two Windows applications) with a specific project file, managing the configuration directly on the HMI, or interfacing with a separate compute module.  Sometimes there were tag count and performance limitations.  Many are inefficient at building and managing the namespace.  A lot of tedious clicking.  Limitations on reusing, renaming, grouping, etc.  It doesn't take long to wonder "Did they just buy a Unified Automation SDK and implement this interface hoping no one would use it?  Wow, this is definitely not an improvement over using the native protocol and third-party gateway like Kepware."

Author: rmawi91
Content:
1. One has to migrate to new firmware and carry out certain changes in programming, also when it comes to s7 PLCs using s7 protocol natively, is faster than Opc ua due to raw binary data being transferred. So Opc ua doesn’t sound that attractive. 

2. However In greenfield and to enable digitalisation, going to be using Opc ua in all siemens PLCs (s7-1500 latest models) and will almost match speed of S7. It will provide meta data, plc information, security. Data size would be obv larger than S7 protocol however it will be capable to meet performance criteria. 

Since ignition does not support auto browsing for siemens PLCs (s7 protocol), instead of using Csv and scripting, with Opc ua, all information would be accessible so it will save quite a lot of time esp any changes made in future or during operations 

So in short, Opc ua is the ideal choice for siemens PLCs w.r.t ignition.

Author: rafaelrrf
Content: My first option is to use the SCADA native driver,  using the equipment protocol, this can cause less overhead in servers and network. Using OPC server can be a good option when the SCADA does not have the PLC driver , third option would be to use the embedded OPC Server in the PLC (for local solutions). My answer is depend on the project.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: My thinking has been that OPC UA subscriptions should have much less overhead than any poll response with native protocols, but I see many prefer native drivers over OPC UA. Am I overestimating how much subscriptions reduces overhead or ??

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I guess it depends on how one defines overhead.  Is it overhead over-the-wire or overhead of the OPC UA Server itself?

I think OPC UA subscriptions is an underrated tool.  It can be beneficial to govern data acquisition centrally rather than on many nodes.  I find that a lot of people aren't familiar with subscriptions and never implement it.  I think, in practice, it can satisfy the "report-by-exception" objective for data acquisition better than MQTT in some cases.  I've seen a lot of real world implementations of MQTT with large, monolithic payloads.  Many publishing nodes lack the sophistication to easily break up the payload or even publish on change.  One does not enjoy the benefits of pub/sub if all data is always moved.  This is not really a function of the protocols themselves, but rather how they're implemented on devices.

I suppose it depends on what the application is.  If one needs to move a lot of data, a bolted on OPC UA Server with tag count limitations may be a problem.  If one needs to move data infrequently or on an event-driven basis, OPC UA Subscriptions or well-implemented MQTT Client can work well.  If one needs fast reads, polling over the native protocol can work well.  There are all sorts of optimizations that can be done with respect to the native protocol and the scanning sequence of memory objects in the device.  

I think it's much more nuanced problem than we realize.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
From what I can tell Tulip uses OPC UA Subscriptions in Kepserver to pull in machine data. This works well for the reasons you describe but one feature that seems to be missing is wildcards. If I have 100 machines to setup, with 10 tags each, I have to manually map in 1000 tags.

I don't have a perfect counter examples for MQTT, but if I want all tags related to a certain area in my business I can do things like, `<sub> ent/site/area/line/+/+/#` in Highbyte and then parse all the data coming in using templates where the topic names themselves can provide a lot of context. 

I still have a lot to figure out but that gets me pretty far.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Can Tulip more intelligently consume machine data over their REST interface?  

If so, would OPC UA "branch" reads or templating in HighByte be easier to configure?

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
More intelligently? No, you map in the raw tags and then create triggers that turn those into information, like machine state, part count, detect idle (operator pauses the program but it's still technically "in cycle"), etc.

I could migrate the machine to an API machine, but I'm not sure that helps. With those you push in tags/attributes over REST but then I have to copy UUIDs for the machine ID and attribute ID out of Tulip and paste them into whatever will be pushing in the data (Node Red, Highbyte, etc.) and I still have to setup triggers.

Author: jon.forbord
