I’d rather have Inductive keep iterating on Ignition, and use Kepserver or some other native-driver expert software with an OPC UA server.. why are the customers so keen on having that native driver inside Ignition? https://inductiveautomation.com/blog/ignition-8131-mitsubishi-driver-update-redundancy-conflict-improvement-perspective-performance-increase

Author: _dyland
Content:
That's an interesting take. As a long time user of ignition (as well as other SCADA platforms) my view is that Ignition's true power is the connectivity. The core of the product is the OPC server and the modules that drive it. Thus, more native modules is an iteration of Ignition. This is evidenced by looking back at the precursor to Ignition FactorySQL, it's only job was to use an opc server to connect PLCs to SQL databases. Factory PMI came and added a GUI and scripting. And that all got merged into what we now know as Ignition.

My typical use case is native drivers where applicable, and edge gateway appliances to bridge incompatible devices. 

That said, this conversation does change depending on how Ignition is used. HMI, SCADA, or MES.

I'm wondering what use cases you have that the native modules failed in?

Also, when you say, "keep iterating on Ignition" what do you mean by "Ignition"? While my take is that Ignition is the OPC server, scripting, and connectivity (looking back to the FactorySQL and FactoryPMI days) not everyone views it that way and that's the beauty of it. I am curious to hear your take.

Author: _dyland
Content: *that said, my big takeaway from the release notes is the change to React 18. That should have some pretty crazy performance boost.

Author: thedavidschultz

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In agreement on this.  While it's nice to consolidate solutions and see more connectivity options in the marketplace, I feel like this is not really the core problem most should be focusing on.  There have existed solutions to solve this problem for decades.  The real challenge has been making whats sent over that protocol useful than the protocol itself.  In my experience, many data acquisition and protocol normalization problems can be solved in minutes or hours with commercial-off-the-shelf solutions.  Putting the data in those payloads to use can take days, weeks, months, etc.  The more that can solve the latter problem, the better off manufacturers will be.

The one area where I can concede native is truly a massive problem is when a protocol is not browsable and the memory objects have primitive addresses (e.g., B10:0/11, R1000.1, M251).  It's non-trivial working through this a protocol gateway or an application with native drivers.  I would like to start seeing some of online repositories or machine builders provide a "data catalog" defining the native memory objects in a way that can be dropped into platforms.  There are too many assets with missing documentation and no comments in the source code.  The industry needs to start publicly pressuring machine builders that don't do this.  And if the standards bodies really wanted to make an impact, they would publicly host repositories for this stuff and allow the market to see who is really delivering on the goal of interoperability.

Possible considerations:
-Cost

Author: og_grendyl
Content: @Idrees , @js Our experience was horrible performance.  We have a mixture of both the older (C-Series) and newer (N-Series) Omron PLCs, and had Ignition on 1 dedicated server and KepServer on another dedicated server, both in our virtual environment.  Kepware's setup and performance on the newer generation PLCs was very similar to that of Ignition.  On the older generation however, after setting up 4 PLCs in Kepware, the data refresh rates were so slow that they were unusable (several seconds when trying to achieve sub-second responsiveness in the system as a whole) and we are typically only reading tag counts in the 10 -  150 range per PLC.  After working with PTC Tech Support to try and improve the performance, their recommendation was to add another NIC for every PLC we needed to connect.  At that point we moved the older PLCs to Ignition's built-in driver, and after they released a driver for the new generation we started using that as well.  We're currently reworking our architecture to have 3 Ignition servers and are eliminating KepServer as part of that change.  The connection monitoring abilities and connection dashboards in Ignition are just icing on the cake for us.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Great info.  Yeah, I've heard the quality of support/collaboration/partnership with Kepware under PTC's stewardship isn't what it once was.  Did you have to do any work with Inductive Automation on creating/enhancing the Omron drivers?

Author: og_grendyl
Content: No, no failures or problems with the drivers.  Prior to Ignition we did have problems with the Omron driver from Indusoft (now Aviva) and they actually had to update the driver due to some problems we found).  But overall Ignition has been great to use.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
Sam from Kepware here. I see this scenario with our Omron FINS driver in our customer environments all the time. 

It's not usually a show-stopper nor does the solution require real physical NICs (I'll talk to Tech Support! We have a few new people who started this year), but it is certainly a Kepware design-inflicted problem that is a big stumbling block. I have personally scoped an architectural resolution with Product Management to correct and honestly this mention / quiet quit moment will be important for them to hear (again).

The current solution might be quick - you need to be able to make one channel per device (FINS-enabled PLC) in order to meet your performance requirement. However, without additional host OS configuration, you can usually only make one channel with the Omron FINs driver, putting all devices below the channel, sharing the driver, and yielding very slow comms.

You can do this - create one channel per device - as long as you have the option of assigning static IPs (receiving a bank of available IPs from IT perhaps). You can "multi-home" your single physical or virtual network adapter by adding additional IPs, and once done, Windows presents those additional IPs as available, independent NICs in the OS. DM if you want the Windows workflow. You'll bind each of those new NICs to a new channel in Kepware.

Context (because who doesn't love Ethernet protocols and history lessons) - like some other native UDP protocols such as BACnet, the authors of the FINS over UDP spec decided to require non-ephemeral, hard-coded source and destination ports. In Kepware, the Channel in most any  driver is the driver's state machine. Way back in the late 1990s, my colleagues decided that the state machine - the channel's thread - is the "owner" of a reserved UDP or TCP port - a port is not reserved "by Kepware" with some general thread and shared intelligently across multiple channels.

Author: bmh1233_17886
Content: hi, can I ask beginner questions?

Author: bmh1233_17886
Content: what is the relationship between PLC and SCADA? I have been told that PLC and HMI is SCADA, but what is the specific relationship between them?

Author: bmh1233_17886
Content: when I read about the topic I get a theoretical explaination, but I would prefer a practical

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
A PLC is commonly an asset-level controller.  An asset's sensors and actuators are connected to it.  The PLC executes a set of instructions based using the sensors as inputs and actuators as outputs.  PLCs are purpose built hardware and software to do this reliably and safely.  If you see an asset running (e.g., a press moving up and down, bioreactor agitating), the asset's PLC is driving this.

A SCADA is software that connects to PLCs.  It's used to monitor PLCs in an area or plant.  This monitoring can consist of visualization, alarming, logging, etc.  It also has the capability to control the PLCs.  This type of control are generally human inputs (e.g., start, stop, process parameters).  It's to "influence" the production process, but not "control" it.  The SCADA does not control the sensors, actuators and cycling of the asset.  The PLC does this.  If you see plant operations personnel looking at a screen with the status and alarm information of many assets, they're looking at a SCADA.

Author: eddiiee_
Content:
Hi, I'm looking at implementing a SCADA system in a factory in Sweden. It's 5 production lines + 16 packing lines, with approx 30 PLC's. Starting with 1 production line + 4 pack. 

The initial plan was to go for Ignition, since we have used it prior in other factories. But considering that 29/30 PLC's are Siemens, and already Siemens HMI's (comfort panels), it seems to be some advantages to go for WinCC instead. thinking about WinCC Unified. I have almost 0 experience with WinCC and only with Ignition. Anyone here that got experience comparing these two?

Are there synergies which lowers cost and implementation time going for Siemens WinCC when you have Siemens PLC's? If that's the case, when would it be justifiable to anyway choose another SCADA, e.g. Ignition? Here I'm assuming that you can copy paste visualizations and tagstructures from the Comfort panels if you go for WinCC but it would need to be done from scratch choosing Ignition. 

Thoughts?

Edit:
Not finding any new good forums/posts/comparisons...
this one is 4 years old and probably much has changed: https://www.reddit.com/r/PLC/comments/cluwu3/wincc_oa_vs_ignition/

Author: akoscs
Content: WinCC is confusing naming. You have WinCC TIA portal (from which I think you have Advanced and Pro versions, probably version 17 right now) then you have WinCC v6 (or maybe 7 idonno) then you have WinCC OA. These are 3 different products! With 30 PLCs, depennding on the amount of data trandsertd and read cycle times (assuming a lot more reads then writes) you may get away with WinCC TIA Portal Professional. Advantage there is that you can directly reuuse all the HMI faceplates (widgets) that you have on the HMIs and you can reuse all the PLC variables very easily. If you go v6 or OA I do not thing that you have any advantage from the dev environmnne point if view since those are not part of TIA portal so still a separate software like Ignition would be. Look at "northbound" interfaces how to integrate the SCADA further up (or make it part of your UNS or whatever your approach integration is), OA is definetly more capable there then any other versions. All of htem are stable tech, if the feature set suites you they work fine. The dev experience is horrible for all of them (but that is kind of true for all SCADAs I worked with, buut I never worked with Ignnition)

Content: We're Siemens heavy on the PLC/HMI side and have been using WinCC SCADA (not OA) for 10+ years. Currently migrating to Ignition as scaling the WinCC platform would be very expensive. I must point out though that we never looked into the OA version of WinCC, and I can't make a fair comparison from an IIoT platform perspective. Also in Sweden, feel free to reach out if you want to have a chat.

Author: jhisw
Content:
Hi, does anyone know an open source SCADA tool, that goes recursively into an OPC UA namespace from a specified node downwards and collects all data?

The only thing I always see is that you have to manually configure every Node-Id to be collected.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You’ll often want to rename, scale or otherwise contextualize the data, particularly if there aren’t friendly symbol names defined in the UA provider.  Not sure the benefits of an automated collection like that are always there. That said, I think Erich Barnstedt has a GitHub repo with code that does something similar.

Author: jhisw
Content:
I agree. 👍  Yet for simple things, it would suffice.
Thanks for the hint. I'll have a look.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: https://github.com/barnstee

Author: ravil1
Content:
@jh-isw, our product ogamma Visual Logger for OPC does something similar to this: https://onewayautomation.com/visual-logger-docs/html/collect.html#auto-discovery-and-selection-of-variables
It is not open source, but free for up to 64 variables. You can control what nodes to browse and select using simple Python scripts (examples provided).

Content: PLC and HMI are used to control equipment. SCADA sits above equipment and includes a data logger or historian.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: It is supervisory and monitors activities at the equipment.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Some plants just have machines with a PLC and HMI and don't really have or need a SCADA.

In process plants with pumps tanks etc a SCADA is essential and you have less HMI,s 

Many sites have a SCADA to control and orchestrate a number of machines and possibly some associated equipment like pumps fans HVAC and the like.

Author: shannonlooper
Content:
Question - how do you usually convert tag databases from one device or platform to another?  

Examples:  

1. I have a ControlExpert program for an M580. I need to export all the HMI tags and import them into InTouch or iFix.
2. I have an InTouch application and I need to export the tags and import them into Ignition.
3. I have a Stuidio5000 application and I need to migrate to ControlExpert.
4. I have a huge tag list from a spec and ten vendors and I need to add them to the PLC project, and the HMI/SADA platform.

This is a recurring event/effort and as a software developer anything I have to do three times I usually write a tool to automate it. Is there a tool for this?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @shannonlooper, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: vaughnturner
Content: @shannonlooper I'll reach out to our team for their thoughts.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Vaughn Turner, you just advanced to level 12!

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
@shannonlooper  here's feedback from our team: 

Michael Walker
To my knowledge there is no platform or tool purpose built for this. Historically I've worked on teams that maintain a database of "tags" generically defined. Each system would be responsible for having the ability to import into and export out of that database structure. This was however mainly done to streamline large documentation efforts in life sciences, not really to solve the problems in the post. We built flows in NodeRed that did the export / import functionality. 

Mario Ishikawa
I agree that there is no easy way, and actually this is one of the things UNS is making easier for higher layers at least. If the conversion is for thousands of tags, I'd create a specific script focused on the conversion from A to B only.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think Corso Systems build something for your second use case (InTouch to Ignition).

Author: shannonlooper
Content:
Second question is, if there was a website where you could upload a flat file export of tags from one source and get back the tags in an importable flat file for another platform, would that be useful and would you pay to use it?

I can see as an integrator that this would be a huge time saver.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Assuming all the tools can export and import tags to a ,csv or similar, Could you use node red, to take the data from a .csv file and reformate the data into another format and upload.

Author: _dyland
Content:
That's what I've done with various formats. I've used Excel, Node Red, Ignition, and just raw python at different times. Most applications can export as some file type . Usually csv, xml, or json. For instance it's not too difficult to export the tag database from iFix as a csv and write a script that reformats it to a json object to import into ignition.

That said, I usually advise against direct or automated conversions on SCADA upgrades. Different platforms have different nuances and limitations and a direct conversion brings all the existing technical debt into the new platform usually bringing out the worst of both and failing to utilize best practices.

Author: _dyland
Content: The hardest part is reverse engineering the formatting of the files.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Chat GPT? " can you write a Json I can import into node red to convert from this file to this file.....
Can you first parse the two files and provide a suggested mapping for each of the fields in the first, and I can review and update."

Or do the first line as an example and ask to extrapolate.

I have done that a few times with taking a csv dump and mapping it int a Broker as per ISA95.

If anyone has some csv's I'm happy to play with ChatGPT and Node red

Author: _dyland
Content: That would get you close enough, yeah.

Author: _dyland
Content:
To give a more concise answer to @shannonlooper original question, 

I think the only real way to do it would be to write the scripts as a custom workflow for your specific needs. With rules defined to enforce custom data types (such as UDTs in Ignition and Studio5000).

Author: shannonlooper
Content:
My DB history is telling me it looks something like "Define tables in a database that matches the file format. That gives a platform specific import target. Define the permissible entries for each field, foreign keys maybe to another table, also one of those set as a default value." I could make a page for manual edits if it needs to be cleaned up. Now I can just make new instances of the database for each load. 

Repeat that for each file format.  Then create the rules for mapping fields from structure A to B.  LLM to the rescue on that bit.

After many databases are defined for many platforms, and the logic to map to other formats. It seems that would get to "load file A and output file type B."

I would use the hell out of it for dumping M580 tags and loading them into InTouch or iFix (yuk).  Actually, I'm surpised Schneider hasn't written that translator yet. They have something to go from XSY files to App Server, but I rarely use App Server in water jobs.

I can see this would not be efficient for people who don't need it that often. I'm thinking about making it a service.

Author: _dyland
Content:
That sounds like a great idea! Most of my conversions have been one offs so I just did some simple scripts to get the results fast. Most fancy I ever got was an API to send the files to and return the new one. But it was always a simple (and throwaway) 1 to 1 conversation. 

Conversion as a service would be a huge timesaver!

Author: shannonlooper
Content: and I just gave away the design 🙂

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: In my experience, the integrators created these tools themselves.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
They have but that is another issue in our Industry.

Integrators , manufacturers and even clients can all create different solutions to the same problem

So instead of leveraging what others have built and creating the next step we spend a lot of time reinventing the wheel.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Not an open source SCADA tool, but HighByte's OPC UA client does exactly this.  It's referred to as a "branch" input type.  It works by specifying the desired root element in the UA namespace and the level of depth.  It gets normalized as an input structure that can be transformed, parsed for modeling, or delivered as-is.

Author: andreasvogler
Content:
automation-gateway.com (open-source) just some lines of yaml configuration is needed.
here is an example config to log values from an opc ua server to kafka,mqtt,influx,iotdb, ...
```
Drivers:  
  OpcUa:
  - Id: "demo2"
    Enabled: true
    LogLevel: INFO
    EndpointUrl: "opc.tcp://192.168.1.3:62541"
    UpdateEndpointUrl: true
    SecurityPolicy: None
          
Loggers:
  Kafka:
    - Id: Kafka1
      Enabled: true
      LogLevel: INFO
      Servers: linux0.rocworks.local:9092
      TopicName: gateway
      Format: Json   
      Logging:
        - Topic: opc/demo2/path/Objects/Demo/#

  InfluxDB:
    - Id: Influx1
      Enabled: true
      Url: http://linux0.rocworks.local:8086
      Database: test
      Logging:
        - Topic: opc/demo2/path/Objects/Demo/#

  IoTDB:
    - Id: IotDB1
      Enabled: true
      Host: linux0.rocworks.local
      Port: 6667
      Database: root.gateway
      Username: "root"
      Password: "root"      
      Logging:
        - Topic: opc/demo2/path/Objects/Demo/#
```

Author: pdmitriev
Content: There is a debate at our company whether SCADA servers must be on-prem or can be in datacenter? Currently, we don’t have any on-prem servers, everything is in data center.  There is a maintainability/supportability concerns with going on-prem. Considering current network technologies is it even that important where server is located? And why? Any feedback is appreciated!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There are inherently cybersecurity and availability/downtime risks associate with any distributed system.  You'll need to assess those risks/threats and make the decision as to how important and critical they are to your business.  I encourage you to do a "red team" analysis, not just for cybersecurity, but also a broad set of "what-ifs" and how they might impact operations.

Author: pdmitriev
Content: Thanks for the feedback, Rick. I believe our cyber security team is on top of this but they don’t really want to “dictate” what infrastructure should be. Their short answer is that they can “secure” any of the configurations under consideration.

Author: pdmitriev
Content: Also, the “what-ifs” sounds like a good exercise to do

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Anyone in your area own a backhoe?  If so, and you rely on your SCADA system to be functioning in order for your factory to be functioning....

Author: pdmitriev
Content: SCADA is just a small piece of a functioning factory, at least for us. Without connection to data center there would be no access to ERP, databases, document systems, PLM, ITAR checks, user authentication, certifications, etc. So yeah, if somebody digs our fiber optic cable out we are screwed, unless there is a backup connection 🙂 This is a known risk that has been assessed and mitigated well as far as I know. Seems like it’s not a valid argument under our circumstances.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Is SCADA the ONLY thing you'd have onsite?   Since it appears you've moved almost everything else to a remote DC?  If so, then yeah, probably not a whole lot of risk..

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
This is what I wrote down (in general, not necessarily comparing to Ignition). 
Just from a demo, haven't used it myself.

WinCC unified is definitely what Siemens is pushing as the future for HMI and most SCADA applications, at least in my market.
Positives: Javascript for scripting, web based (in ISS), svg graphics (although their own svghmi format), limited graphQL interface, automation possible via TIA openness api
Negatives: TIA portal (not only a clunky piece of sh*t, but also pay for dev), no redundancy option (yet), less mature, only on Windows (except for Siemens panels), no flat files (forget git), licensing model

Ignition anyday.

Author: rutger_18900
Content: please elaborate, like I said just based on a first view and biased, happy to be corrected

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Context: Unified got introduced to keep up with the web-based HMI (competitors had it, Siemens had to have it as well) & to simplify the productgamma of the Siemens HMIs. 

Wincc unified is also targeted to OT people; it's not worried about GIT for example. An ot guy wants  templates, that's way easier. No one cares that you can insert costum html5 code to have nice visuals. OT needs a motor to move and an operator needs to be able to start it from the screen. Nothing more, nothing less.

From working with Unified the main takeaways are; time to market was too short; first 2 versions (V16 & V17) were too buggy to be production worthy; from V18 on it's actually quite good software.

Drawbacks would be from an ot engineers perspective; 
- the overly complex licensing model (already way better then WinCC flexible,advanced,basic,(OA)) => people cant select and buy as is possible for ignition
-available features. (it's missing features that we're available in older siemens scada products) => migration is difficult but phase out is planned in 2025 for wincc advanced (Siemens is forcing everyone to migrate to unified)
- IP67 panels are hardly available yet
-UL certification for certain models is lacking

Advantages would be:
-Javascript instead of VBA (self explaining haha)
- Webbased options
- web, PC & panel based options available
- fully implemented in TIA portal ❤️ 
- it's all way cleaner and modern than previous available options

things like the graphQL interface, yeahh nice (thanks @Andreas Vogler) but i've not seen this used in reality yet. This would be for very IT savy people not for OT people

Author: diederik9434
Content: I kind of like unified but it's no ignition for sure

Author: diederik9434
Content:
and be asure; at siemens they feel the very real competition of Ignition
3 years ago sales would be laughing at you; now they know

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Work in a test engineering lab with some of the following eqpt:
- environmental chambers
- DAQ multiplexers (keysight measurement system)
- linux servers (dozens)
- general sensors ...

We need a means to:
- integrate all eqpt into a single "system"  (some are RESTful, some have GPIO, servers need bash + filestore for test setups)
- provide a GUI to interface with the equipment
- automate our existing workflow, using the GUI (set environmental conditions, start DAQ sampling, start test scripts and logs)

I looked into inductive, but i worry that its an added layer of complexity

Node red is too simple for our workflows

Any tools, technologies etc to suggest?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
It sounds like you want to build a SCADA as in

You want something to get data from different sources and allow and interface to supervise and control.

Your system is more of an IT environment than a process or manufacturing one if I understand correctly.

When you say Inductive adds a layer of complexity, it sounds like you are going to need to add a layer on top of your system in one way or another. Is it you are unfamiliar with it?

You could look at Litmus or HighByte to capture data and normalise and contextualise it into a single 'system'. And then add a GUI in whatever format you want.

I am surprised node red is too simple for your needs. But you could deploy node red locally on there servers and manage it with FlowFuse and get a better Interface with Dashboard 2.0

Or try looking at the UMH.io

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Great suggestions.

Re: Inductive & complexity, yes it seems like I'd have to learn Inductive + every other system in the environment, and guess Im concerned Inductive would "add" complexity. I dont think these instruments have OPC UA, or fieldbus io...

Same goes for the chambers....i guess if you have multiple equipment from multiple non-compatible vendors, how do you put them together to enable a consistent cross systrm interface? Is SCADA the right tool? 

Maybe (to your point) this is more IT /SW integration?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The Right tool is a Platform, that can take the different protocols and access types and  allow you have a single system. 

Ignition ( and other SCADA's) have been used by OT because they normally have a lot of device drivers and they can connect and get all the data into one manageable place to have a "Single System".

Today there are better platforms for pulling in data from different sources, E.g. Litmus or HighByte.
And they are really designed to allow you scale, because that is impossible to do effectively with a SCADA.

But I don't think Scaling to 10 Labs is in your plan, and you still need some Gui/Visualisation on top of that?

Do you know, what Data you want from your sources and how you can connect?

Author: xamp4248
Content: I have a use case where I need to transfer data from 5000 transmitter values from a PLC to SQL at 1-second intervals. I've tried using both Ignition and Litmus, but neither solution was completely successful. Although Ignition performed better than Litmus, it still failed to write the data accurately, with some columns recording zero values. Anyone can suggest a more efficient method?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You'll want to batch insert those values, not one at a time.

Author: xamp4248
Content: Yes. Continuous.. Not one time

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I meant that you should be doing transactions that do multiple inserts, not one transaction for each value.

Author: xamp4248
Content: Got it. Thanks. But if i need all the sensor values for the same time?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: No, but in batches of 50-100 would be ideal. What database are you storing them in?

Author: xamp4248
Content: SQL server

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Read the documentation regarding BEGIN TRANSACTION/COMMIT TRANSACTION, and do a series of inserts between those statements.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
best thing about labview, anyone can develop a 'working' solution relatively quickly.
worst thing about labview, anyone can develop a 'working' solution relatively quickly.

Author: zeratall
Content: What about on a unreliable network, is it better to lose 1 point, or (if your really unlucky) a number of points because it’s batched? Batching helps with db performance and most people are on a rock solid 4x9 network, so batching is a solid recommendation but architecture is always “depends” and hardly ever “absolute”

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Don’t lose a thing! Edge buffering isn’t hard to do.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: All data stores benefit from batching. You’d have to test it.

Author: thunt.career
Content:
The same argument for any software or tool and that is understanding the long term plan for maintenance and support. Certain tools or solutions are ripe for abuse. Labview can be the right tool in the certain situations. 

However, some times it's implemented by a R&D team for a specific trial because that's what they used in college and it ends up being successful so they promote the machine to full production. Rather than revisit the software and architecture, they keep it and add some NI DAQs to communicate to half the VFDs and other I/O on the  machine and add a PLC which talks to the other half. The R&D team has moved onto other jobs and now 10 years later you have this solution that has very little local support because Labview is not the typical tool from the PLC integrators you work with.

Now I believe certain parts of automotive have strong Labview support with solid integrators around Michigan.

At the end of the day, it isn't just about deploying some awesome software and patching the immediate problem. Just because you can develop something cheaply doesn't mean you should and there should be definite warning bells if the business can't justify a solution financially.

Content: I'm all for boring naming, I like it when the name of the product tells me roughly what it does, and I think AVEVA does a decent job at that.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Also INSIDE the (at least the former ww) products, e.g. ISA95 structure and nomenclature in MES products, naming an object an object, a client a client, and so on.
I'd prefer it to go even further though, for exemple in (A?)SP calling it application instead of "galaxy", node instead of "platform", service instead of "engine", ...
Why does every vendor make us learn new made up names for the same thing? To lock us in I guess?

Similarly, I've done some projects for a company where they worked for example with Rockwell FactoryTalk and Siemens OpCenter, but the company (mfg, end user) gave these products and their components different names internally (also completely made up).
This resulted in people having product experience (highly sought after in the job market) and them not knowing it, even listing (only) the company specific names on their cv, so only people who've worked with this specific company would know what their experience really was.
I guess it works.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Although in case of renaming in an M&A company like AVEVA (not trying to single them out, Siemens is the same and there are others, but as an example) idk how beneficial it is for the end user. 
While clarifying the purpose, it's hard to gauge how well these products actually play together, and there seem to be competing products in the portfolio as well.

Hard to know what I want/need to future-proof my operations here.
- WonderWare InTouch --> AVEVA InTouch HMI
- WonderWare (A)SP --> AVEVA System Platform
- Citect SCADA --> AVEVA Plant SCADA
- OASyS SCADA --> AVEVA Enterprise SCADA
- WonderWare historian --> AVEVA Historian
- Osisoft PI--> AVEVA PI System

For the sake of architecture diagrams HMI may be used to define the front end application (thick or thin) and I would break SCADA into the various components in use.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It first helps to learn more about SCADA does and how it may be implemented.  Check out the video below.  At a high level, data from SCADA includes data from PLCs in a supervisory context.  Imagine if one were sitting in a control room or in front of plant- or -area-level HMIs.  These would include current state and telemetry data of many assets.  This, in practice, is a subset of the data in the PLC, but often very valuable data for many use cases.  There might also be alarm and event data present.  In addition to this data, there may be additional context with human inputs.  The SCADA screens might have commands to automation, alarm acknowledgements, and other components users interact with.  These can be used to capture the "intent" of the automation (e.g., line 1 was started at 07:00 by operator x, but went down at 07:05 with alarm y, but was acknowledged at 7:10 citing reason z).

https://youtu.be/nlFM1q9QPJw?si=2Ya6DPFWje4J_K2g

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Some SCADA solutions have drivers to connect to devices that only support native protocols.  Sometimes the SCADA solutions don't have all drivers or functionality.  Or, there might be a desire to decouple device connectivity with a dedicated solution.  They'll use a protocol gateway that adapts the native device protocols into a normalized protocol like an OPC UA.

Interestingly, some SCADAs with device drivers internally normalize the data as an OPC UA or OPC DA server.

This video explains the history behind OPC and device drivers welll:
https://youtu.be/JgsuQrSlFF8?si=QgLDCdI6MfmSTg2G&t=388

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Why no just 1 PC with the 4 monitors? I have being on control rooms that have 12 monitors on 3 PCs, the mouse/keyboard handling was already messy. Dont see the point of adding more PCs

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I like to keep things standard and I want to be able to quickly get a SCADA back up an running.
If the standard Desktop in stores always has 4 monitors , great. 
But now I am adding maybe 600 dollars onto my PC cost, on every PC that doesn't need 4 displays.

Typically I would have used Thin clients and the standard Thin client spec would be 2 ports and there would be plenty in stores.
And  for probably less cost than a Desktop with a graphics card for 4 ports, I would now have redundancy in my Plant room so if I desktop fails or reboots I have another one running. 

 That might be the difference between me needing to drive 50- miles to a plant at 3am to fix a PC or install a new one. and then by the time in Install the SCADA software the plant has been down for 4 hours. With a Second desktop the plant can run until I get in at a normal time.

And with the two desktop PC I used to have two OI servers( Intouch/Wonderware) so if the OI server crashed on the SCADS desktop it could use the OI server running on the backup. 

And a lot of my experience would be an operator station with multiple operators, so have two keyboards and mouses helped too

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
I'm in Germany.  I think that the login thing is out of an overabundance of caution relating to the Lieferkettengesetz (literally: supply chain law), which has been active since January 2023.  It applies to companies based in Germany with more than 3000 employees, and since January 2024 to those with 1000 employees.  They are required to know who their business partners are, and be able to document interactions with them.  The motivation was protection of human rights, children, environment and so on - the responsibility should not belong only to the final manufacturer but to the whole supply chain.

A random person trying out demo software is _not_ a business partner, however, and the software isn't part of anybody's supply chain at that point.  The law is more about supplier verification than consumer - supermarket chains don't ask who I am when I buy food.  I cannot see that registration for downloads is a legal requirement, but I guess many company lawyers aren't sharing my opinion, or are just playing it safe.

Content:
What is the difference between UOC and OMI? Does UOC come with templates whereas OMI does not?

Content: Yes it is, what’s the issue ?

Author: loris6780
Content: UOC at the end is not more than OMI (SystemPlatform) including a lot of apps and other software from Aveva (or not) in one single visualization node (multiple screens), putting everything in context. You may have GMAO solutions, ERP data, 3D symbols, Videos, Map information, Asset information that you want to bring together in the same screens. What’s important to understand is that if you change or click as exemple on a different asset in the map app all the other apps or soft will understand that the context has changed and will show their information on the new selected asset. Aveva offers multiple UOC - application made by them with libraries etc

Author: firstgriller
Content: Gotcha. Yah UOC would be better from a top end view. Whereas we use OMI for a plant level view.

Author: loris6780
Content: Yes indeed

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Vendor lock, they want us to work on it to
- Adjust the data
- Add more visualization for addtional systems
- Make a Unified Namespace at the backend with another tool to model the data before the UOC subscribe to the data.

On a quick glance, it should be similar to Ignition Perspective with more ready to use widgets and template.

My question: Is it a data producer as well as consumer? Can I get data out of it to use? I.e. does it have an OPC-UA Server or a REST-API server that I can get the KPIs out to Snowflake and PowerBI?

Author: loris6780
Content: Well, it will be much more powerful than ignition perspective. It can be a data consumer or producer. You may want to use OI Gateway to consume data from OPC UA servers. You can start a service to make the UOC act as a opcua server (only the live. Data). Depending on the UOC it might include Aveva Historian or/and Aveva Pi, so basically there are several possibilities to connect snowflake and Powerbi. You can build whatever you want in terms of graphics just reuse their librairies duplicate and change. The UOC comes with a ISa95 approach so it might be quick to create the UNS asides.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Thanks 😊 'Much more powerful than Perspective' sounds interesting.

I see the Aveva Historian in the license list. Can you tell me a little more about it? I know that it uses MS-SQL but can other product connects to it and read the data in the SQL database? Is there a way to aggregate the data and store them in a table that can be queried?

Author: loris6780
Content: Any sql client or via odata as well, in the windows button go to aveva documentation and search for aveva historian retrieval - you’ll get what you need. Also the aveva database schema pdf exposes the runtime db primary key/secondary between tables. And other documents might be helpful. If you don’t have these documents, it means that it wasn’t installed, so search for the system platform iso using the same version as your uoc. Open the iso via windows explorer and search for .pdf it will list all help files. The runtime database is a metadata database only so it doesn’t grow or has to be maintained. Data are in folder called history blocks in the circular folder. Aggregation happens in the object from the aaide then the result can be store in the history blocks and the metadata linked to the aggregation tag will be logged only once in the runtime db of historian.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
Saying "it's so much more powerful than ignition" is something I see a lot by AVEVA distributors and AVEVA-only integrators, always without properly backing up the claim.

@Loris have you done any projects with ignition before making such claims? Are there any non-AVEVA products you can recommend?

I've worked a lot with ASP in the past and it is absolutely a great product! But so is Ignition and it's a lot more accessible, cheaper, and easy to administer. 

I can see the value in predefined templates though, as @vikan mentioned, same goes for DCS systems vs custom PLC libraries.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I would love to put them side by side because it has been a few years but looking a Aveva System Platform, and Ignition .
Is the Objects and model structure not much more powerful than what Ignition can do with UDT's. 
You are forced into proper governance which frustrates you an small jobs but saves you at scale.

I'm not a naturally ordered mind, and I would be really worried that an Enterprise Ignition system would end up administrable because if deviations etc, especially where multiple vendors are working in the same  enterprise and I have different UDT's for different motors . It is much easier to enforce a single model for a motor in System platform, even if at a PLC level they are different.

but it would be really good to do a road test especially between InTouch and Ignition. I suspect they are closer than people think.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
What is it that makes the SP object template so different from the Ignition UDT, and easier to enforce?

Different integrators working on the same system will be a mess in both cases if  you don't have proper governance rules. 

I agree that probably InTouch is closer to Ignition than people think. 

Is it scalable though? Or are you forced towards ASP if you want a distributed system? Not sure, genuine question. 
And how does AVEVA do with non-windows systems and containers? 

I would love to see a proper side by side between Ignition, InTouch and ASP!

Again, I still think ASP is a great platform.

I'm just allergic to people claiming "A is so much better than B" without backing it up. Especially if all they ever worked with (or worse, for) is A.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
They can! There's tag event scripts you can configure on your tags within UDT.

I can definitely understand the preference for having visualization embedded in the object template.
They can be linked in Ignition, but they're not in 1 place, both approaches have pros and cons in my opinion.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
One thing that's a BIG pro in ASP over Ignition in my opinion is having proper identifiers.

In Ignition everything is only referenced by name (string including location), like having filenames and folders.
You really have to think ahead about naming and structuring everything, or rely on external tools I guess.

Change the name (or location) of anything (UDT, tag, view, folder, ...) and you're in for a bad time, all your references will be broken.

Author: loris6780
Content:
To clarify my thoughts a bit, in Vikan’s case, the customer either wants or already has a UOC (Unified Operations Center). We're talking about a hypervision tool where all your business software solutions are integrated to display information, helping you analyses and take decisions. We're not referring to SCADA in this context, even though the UOC may be built on SCADA software (ASP + OMI), as it includes or can include much more.

At this level of control, direct command functionality isn’t necessarily a priority, although it's still possible to incorporate it. Many customers use various solutions at different levels of the stack (EMS, CMMS, ERP, MES, HMIs, dashboarding tools, etc.). For these customers, it can be challenging to quickly gather all the necessary information from these systems to make informed decisions.

One of the goals of UNS was to address this, but it doesn’t fully solve the need to centralize key visualization information on the same screens and have them work harmoniously by adapting to a changing context. The idea is that, within one container (OMI here), you can integrate as much key information as possible by embedding other software solutions. When the context in one changes, the others will automatically adjust to reflect the new context

I don’t yet have a comparison with other software, but based on what I’ve seen OMI accomplish (with around 30 out-of-the-box apps like PowerBI, Sankey, PLC code viewer, Pi Vision, map apps, graphic repeater, content presenter, etc.), it’s quite impressive. They also provide the ability to create your own apps by offering an SDK. This is why, in a nutshell, I can confidently say it’s much more powerful than Ignition for this particular use case.

Author: loris6780
Content:
Now, getting into more technical details: yes, objects are more powerful than UDTs, but they aren’t always necessary. What I find particularly interesting about objects is their ability to include wizards for attributes, scripts, and graphics. If you associate these graphics with a symbol wizard it makes it very powerful. However, again, it’s not always necessary and yes it might become overkill for some customers. 

Where I find Ignition better than ASP would be in terms of web client - Aveva has to work on that - as well as their capability to be decoupled of  Windows..

Author: loris6780
Content: Aveva Historian for operation software (intouch, plant scada, ASP, Aveva Edge, etc) all having store and forward and out of the box connectors (HCAL protocol) and are able to push the data through a dmz. Historian has his own replication to tier 2 Aveva PI. PI is an enterprise historian much more able to connect other devices/sources, having Asset Framework and more calculations possibilities. Historian publish the model view (isa95) in Asset Framework as soon as the replication starts - no alarms but there are solutions. So Aveva Historian more affordable close to your production, Aveva Pi as enterprise Historian

Author: markpitout
Content:
I see all these conversations about the costs and effort required to add a historian to a SCADA, and then I look with renewed appreciation at EcoStruxure Geo SCADA. The historian is built-in at zero cost, and configuring data to historize is a simple as ticking a box in the tag configuration. 
We have customers with historized data in their Geo SCADA systems, going back as far as ten years.

Author: markpitout
Content: And another nice feature of having the historian built into the SCADA, is that data validation and correction are standard features that require no extra engineering.

Author: _dyland
Content:
These conversations aside, even at 500,00 tags in Ignition with probably half of them historized - I have never run into an issue with the built in historian. The values are just not changing fast enough to be a concern.

On top of that, Ignition is adding the "Power Historian" in 8.3 - This is just QuestDB under the hood and should blow their previous ingestion rate and compression out of the water.

The issues really come in at a large enterprise scale and with architectures that were made for the site level.

Author: _dyland
Content: I have integrated Timescale, InfluxDB, and QuestDB as external "Historians" in ignition - the level of effort to store the data is negligible. The effort comes in recreating the aggregation and specific functionalities that come built into "Industrial Historians". More so the effort to maintain the systems that create that functionality and the infrastructure to accommodate it.

Author: _dyland
Content:
In a smaller enterprise I would agree but I really want the data logged at the edge where the traffic is the easiest to manage. The SCADA and the Historian should each push data to the UNS.

The Historians should be able to be aggregated from the UNS but if I have 4 sites with 500,000 tags it will be a lot easier to ingest that data locally (Even per Line or Area) than to try and push that all through a UNS especially when Cloud comes into the picture. 

I am really optimistic that as Timebase from Flow Software matures it will help with this too.

Author: andreasvogler
Content: I would like to learn what those "historians" are - what makes them special compared to a time-series database? Is it that they have connectivity to multiple sources? Is it that they have special query options focused on time-series data? Is it a easy-to-use management software? Also compared to a SCADA system with an embedded data historization - like WinCC OA or Ignition has - writing tag data to different databases, like Oracle, InfluxDB, PostgreSQL, ... hope the community can enlighten me.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: They usually have a concept of tags and other entities that can be organized and browsed to mirror your assets.  Most pure time series DBs do not.

Author: expi3pi
Content:
Historians are purpose built for the industry, they are mostly a toolbox that contain out-of-the-box functionality that would require a lot of additional tools around a 'traditional' time-series database. Historians have a nice UI for administration and an API or SDK, and are therefore more accessible to less technically inclined people. Typical functionalities are easy central management of data collectors, modelling of assets, calculation engine, event detection, built-in visualisation of data, etc.

With SCADA systems with embedded historisation, the historisation part is 'usually' an afterthought. The output of a historian should be a very stuctured dataset that can easily and quickly be queried.

Author: rickysunkwokshing
Content:
A historian is a specialized database for storing and analyzing time-series data from industrial processes, like those in oil and gas or manufacturing. Instead of using the historian in a SCADA system, an independent historian (e.g., AVEVA PI) offers several advantages:

Scalability: Handles larger data volumes and faster retrieval.
Data Integration: Combines data from multiple SCADA/DCS systems into one platform.
Advanced Analytics: Provides tools for in-depth analysis, anomaly detection, and reporting.
Reliability: Designed with redundancy and backup for high data availability.
Security & Compliance: Offers advanced security features and audit trails.
Long-Term Storage: Suitable for years of data retention, unlike SCADA historians, which may focus on short-term storage.
These capabilities make independent historians ideal for comprehensive, data-driven decisions in complex environments.

Author: du5tins
Content:
Hi, long time lurker and geo scada SME. 

Oh the SE rumor mill. 😂 This is the first I have heard this rumor though. It likely doesn’t make sense to switch out the historian in Geo scada. The historian is tightly, TIGHTLY integrated into the product. Plus it is performant for most queries and OT/HMI use cases. In my limited experience with PI and comparing them side by side; Geoscada historic queries almost always returned results faster than PI. On top of that It’s not really a module that can be easily “switched out” for something different, nor can I see how switching that part out would add value to the product at all. 

SE did take the alarm functionality from Geo scada and applied it to Citech in the mid-2010’s. Back when it seemed like they might merge the code bases. So there is precedent for switching parts of the software out. 

What I can also confirm is that Geo Scada has native connectors to export/stream historical data to WWH, eDNA, and now Aveva PI. The PI export stuff was added in the last major release.

Author: jorgenk1000
Content: Hi all, we`re mapping out all our sites and we see in some of our bigger sites we have Rockwell PlantPax DCS. At some similiar sites we have upgraded (not from PlantPax but from another custom SCADA application which had reached end of life) to Ignition. Question now is, should PlantPax be replaced by ignition? I have no experience with PlantPax with an Industry 4.0 perspective, so I am uncertain what to recommend. The guys on the respective sites are happy with PlantPax as a solution so I guess what I would like to know is how open it is and how well it integrates into eg. UNS and so on?

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'll preface this by saying that I despise PlantPAX, I have researched it, evaluated it, demoed it, and I have actively refused to bid on projects that required it because I have never personally seen an implementation where the end user was happy with it. That's not even to say anything about the cost of implementing it... Monetary and employee morale.

That said. 

If it's already in place, especially if it's working for you - don't rip it out... Ripping out PlantPax and replacing it with Ignition is not just a SCADA swap but the PLC, Historian, and basically the entire architecture. It's an expensive and high risk project that is unlikely to have any real ROI. 

If it wasn't working for you, or causing other issues I might have a different recommendation... But don't rip and replace without a damn good reason.

PlantPAX is not I4.0 compatible but you can use some other tools to integrate the sites into a larger enterprise architecture that is.

Basically, PlantPAX will be a single, very large, node.

FactoryTalk Linx (OPC-UA) and FactoryTalk Historian are probably your best points to connect to.

I would probably look at tools like Flow Software and/or Highbyte to connect, collect, and analyze the data while bridging it you larger 4.0 architecture.

Author: du5tins
Content:
Dylan’s answer is spot on. We use PlantPAx a lot and it’s not really I4.0 ready. And it can only be called Plant PAx if all the components from the I/O to the HMI are PAx certified. 

We have contemplated building an Ignition flavour of the library. The heavy lift to build, test, debug, then deploy it would be unreal for one company to do on their own, for maybe not a lot of benefit. 

Time to value is probably key here. Rip and replace doesn’t always generate a lot of immediate value. First thought for me is leave Plant PAx in place and find fast ways to get the data out to your UNS and digital infrastructure. Maybe Ignition is there beside FTV SE for a time to get data flowing? When hardware upgrade times come, evaluate options that fit your technical requirements in your digital strategy.

If you want to build a UNS based architecture for I4.0 I would stay away

It's a few years or of date but I once lost a project that I quoted for a significant, I believe 7 figure difference between us and the winning bid.

The difference was we were not using PlantPax. So we didn't need AB MCCs, PCs, Servers, and switches. Ours was a custom build with Ignition and AB PLCs but not PlantPax. 

The client required PlantPax but we were told to bid anyways.... They went with one of the PlantPax options and I heard from a few of their operators a year later that they all left cause it never really worked for their use case.

Almost 10 years ago we evaluated PlantPax vs a custom PlantPax style system using Ignition. I'm on v3 of that custom solution.

AB PLCs and Ignition for SCADA and MES.

Author: du5tins
Content:
So many variables we do not know! Haha. I'd suggest that it would be Ignition (least), FTV SE (mid, but not much more than Ignition), and Plant PAx (most). 

Maybe this is sacrilege to say out loud but the Plant PAx building blocks are simply prescribed (aka supported) AB Control Logix or compact logix PLCs and I/O, coded with PAx instructions, connected to a FTV SE HMI, using PAx graphics design, on a prescribed network and server architecture. Plant PAx is marketed as a different product even though the system will have all the same components as a typical Rockwell control system with a FTV SE front-end. Its a marketing play with some added technical bits that enable the system to compete against other DCS systems more directly and eliminate the integrator wildcard. 

FTV SE (and by extension PlantPAx) is a dead-end for data flow for sure. It'll be alright for operator visualization and maybe light alarm management but not really a data platform. Its the HMI in the automation stack. 

Hopefully this information is helpful.

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: How many HMI clients will you need? That's a big factor. With Ignition you have a one-time cost for unlimited clients. With PlantPax/Factory Talk you will pay by the client. The last PlantPax project I was on only had two HMI clients and that portion alone was around $12K-$15K. For that price you get unlimited clients.

Author: _dyland
Content:
It's been a couple years but I've bid systems where we had to price both FactoryTalk SE and Ignition as separate options. 

In my experience, Ignition was always cheaper for systems that were more than a single client with 25 screens. Adding redundancy only expanded that gap... Adding a historian further expanded that gap... 

Not to mention the lack of a global scripting context... In the Rockwell stack, I still prefer working on View 32 to View SE.

Add the developer experience and the end user experience and it's not a competition. 

Optix may have closed the gap a bit but I haven't gotten much time on it

Author: _dyland
Content: I recently quoted a project where a full ignition gateway with the historian was cheaper than 4 panel views, hardware included.

Author: _dyland
Content: Not to mention the price of the Dev software.

Author: _dyland
Content:
In my opinion, you can compare Optix, System Platform, WinCC OA, and Frameworx to ignition no problem some may even beat it in some scenarios.

View SE is in the legacy category.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'm going to lay off Rockwell for a bit after this... But my issue with PlantPax aside from price, is FactoryTalk View SE.

I have been down this road and been burned before. I have done multiple projects that required heavy data integration where we used it and it was always a significant effort to build anything that remotely met our standards.

I never want to build an MES on FTV SE again.

Author: _dyland
Content: But yeah, I'm backing off after this one. Time for more positive contributions from here 🙂

Author: _dyland
Content: And again, this is all just my opinion based on my personal experience.

Author: nathan.slider
Content: Geo SCADA Expert 2023 released Feb 2024, they put a feature in the product to create native Publishing (using the SDK)  to PI or CONNECT using the PI Web API OMF (Open Message Format) For awarness "OMF itself does not define or depend on any particular binary message protocol (HTTP, AMQP, Kafka, etc.) It is instead based on an abstract message type, where a message consists of a set of key / value pairs, called the headers, and a binary payload, called the body. OMF messages can thus be constructed using any message protocol that defines headers and bodies."

Author: nathan.slider

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Ha. Genesis has been around for MANY years and has always been a well kept secret. Even more of a secret after Mitsubishi bought it. They were frequently pioneers in adopting the latest Microsoft technology and also OPC/OPC UA. Some of the leadership team were instrumental in OPC.

Author: andymellor
Content: I worked there for 10 years. They were very allied to Microsoft and won the Microsoft industry partner of the year award a few times. Focussed on OPC Classic and then released a new .NET version in 2010 that was OPC UA based. This is the current version Genesis 64.  I think they recently added minimal MQTT support.  They have a reasonably fast historian - similar to Canary, decent analytics tools and pretty amazing 3D visualisation tools for those willing to invest the time. The main difficulty that people had was the modular configuration, each module required separate configuration - this might have changed.

Author: vikanchira

Author: zaxonite
Content: Hey guys, new to the renewables and power industry as an intern and I’ve come across Phasor Measuring Units (PMUs) and Wide Area Monitoring Systems (WAMS) and was wondering if this is something SCADA softwares like Ignition stays away from. It seems like these systems are kept separate from SCADA because of data structure and frequency of polling as guided in the IEEE C37.118 standard. I’ve just never come across a system like that before, it’s foreign to me

Author: iiot_goat
Content:
https://inductiveautomation.com/exchange/2737/overview This resource has Phasor Measuring Units and integration with Comtrade data files for grid monitoring in Ignition. There are other open sources tools available to integrate this type of data with a PI Historian. The main hurdle for more SCADA integrations with respect to PMUs is the relatively high data monitoring rate compared to a lot of SCADA systems polling rates so you typically need to set these up as a separate data source or manage some higher speed polling in your SCADA system which can put a drain on your resources if you are looking at more than a handful of phasors. 

Siemens has some hardware options that can help manage this as well. https://www.siemens.com/us/en/products/energy/energy-automation-and-smart-grid/protection-relays-and-control/general-protection/phasor-measurement-unit-pmu.html

Author: espen7732
Content:
Hi everyone! 👋

I've been working on a technical comparison document between major SCADA platforms – including Ignition, Niagara Framework, Siemens WinCC, AVEVA Plant SCADA, and GE iFIX – with a focus on:

Building automation and water/wastewater systems
Licensing models and scalability
Protocol support (BACnet, OPC UA, MQTT, Modbus)
Edge computing and Unified Namespace
Open data access and integration with IT systems

📝 I’ve tried to keep it practical, vendor-neutral, and based on real-world use cases.
💬 I’d love your feedback in a private messeage – especially if:

Something is technically inaccurate
You see bias in any direction
You think there’s something missing or could be explained better
You have field experience that could help strengthen the conclusions
